productPageReviews.reviewTitle: A mixed bag, but worth it if you're a big fan of the series...
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: ...and I do mean if you're a BIG fan of the series. I'll say up top that this book definitely isn't for people who aren't into the series on a "I consume the expanded lore" level. Not because I'm trying to gatekeep, or because only people well acquainted with the lore will understand the plot; but because, to put it frankly, it kinda drags for most of its read-time. As a direct novelization of the game Halo: Combat Evolved, most of the plot in the book is re-treading the exact plot of the source material. And by direct, I mean direct. Where in a video game, repeatedly shooting aliens in hallways can be loads of fun, it is much less interesting to read about someone shooting aliens in hallways. And this is often handled in such a way that the words start blurring together. The chapter that covered the level "The Library" was particularly grueling, with pages of text that all could be summarized as "He shot the enemy, then moved forward and shot more enemy." Almost all of the parts covering events in the source material read this way, which admittedly can be neat at times - particularly in how some events and environments are described in ways that make me go "oh, I remember that exact room/combat encounter/etc." But overall, most things dealing with Chief reads like a play-by-play of someone's playthrough of the game, which is less than interesting.This is contrasted, however, by the parts not focusing on events presented in the game, which are well written and fun to read. They don't always hit spot on, and in particular the scenes of fighting tend to get bogged down, but William Dietz's capabilities as an author shine much brighter when he's unshackled from pre-established events. Of particular note are the side plots concerning Yayap, a grunt working for an elite headhunter with a mission to hunt down Chief, and Lt. Melissa McKay, a marine leader coordinating and fighting in the resistance against the covenant. Both are quite fun, and I enjoyed them a lot.Another thing of particular note is the personality given to the characters, and the overall energy and tone of the book. They all feel particularly "mean" or "angry" or just "off" in some way or the other. Its Halo, so of course death is a common occurrence, but a lot of the killings feel mean-spirited or particularly cruel in how they're described, which is an odd thing to hone in on for a book about war, but I noticed it a lot over my read and it really didn't feel to be in the same vain is the more serious action in books like "Fall of Reach" and "Contact Harvest" or the more fun, not-afraid-to-be-playful feel of the games like Halo 2 or 3. Well established characters like the Master Chief and Cortana also seem "off-model" so to speak in their characterizations, with the duo's relationship feeling more full of anger toward each other rather than the sarcastic, yet supportive rapport they are known for having. I can't really blame Dietz for his mischaracterizations too much though, seeing as how this was quite literally the third piece of major Halo media ever released. There just wasn't that much there to guide things like tone and personality, and while the gleeful violence seems more Doom than Halo - and definitely not to my liking - I can respect the situation the author was in when this was written.Overall, while I like a lot of the additions to the story of Halo this book brings, the overall package isn't something that I can see people enjoying too much unless they're looking for those additions in particular. If not, you're better off playing Combat Evolved.CONS:- The action is monotonous and boring.- Lots of telling you what happens instead of showing.- The tone is weirdly angry and cruel.- The established characters don't really feel like themselves.- You've already seen the main plot if you've played Halo: CE.PROS:- Some of the side characters and their stories are interesting and fun. (This is what made me choose 3 instead of 2 stars, by the way. There are some very good times to be had in the B plots, just not enough to make the whole package good instead of mediocre.)- We get to see a more complete view of the battle that takes place in Halo: CE.- It is canon that Chief drives the warthog into the building in "Silent Cartographer."

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Another great addition to an incredible series! Can't stop reading
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Another good one! Brushfire was exactly what I hoped forâ€”packed with action, humor, and the kind of intergalactic trouble that only Joe Bishop and Skippy the AI can get into! The story hits the ground running with new twists and plenty of banter, which kept me laughing and turning pages. If you're already a fan of the Expeditionary Force series, this book wonâ€™t disappoint. Itâ€™s more of the same epic space battles and clever dialogue that makes this series so addictive. Definitely a fun read for fans!Alanson's imagination is mind-blowing. This series is so long, and I can't begin to imagine having the talent to write a series that has kept me engaged this far into it. I'm not an astrophysicist so I can't attest to this, but the space travel and battle physics seem very plausible to me, which further enhances the series. I'm not left feeling like it's unrealistic or 'fanciful.'If you like sci-fi and are open to a good dose of comedy and human interaction interspersed, I highly recommend this book and the series.EDIT: added a fan image of Skippy. Not perfect, just a first stab at it.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2024

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Expeditionary forces is always funny and well paced. The action draws you in. The characters grow on you then next thing you know you've finished 11 books and hope they keep coming. These are books I will reread again and again.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on January 9, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This book, 11th in the series, started off well. Plenty of action "out there," but then it bogged down and wallowed in the middle with what seemed a load of fill up padding. It started reading like a romance novel, (not that I ever read those). So much so that I found it a chore to keep reading, but pressed on, thinking that this was the final book in the series and wanted to see how it all ended - more about that later. I'm glad I did keep going because the action revved back up again and Allanson's inventive mind (or was it Bishop's or Skippy's) came up with a highly imaginative chain of events that I would never have expected. As I mentioned above, I thought this was the last book in the series because of what the author had said when he first launched the ExForce series. In fact, book 10 was supposed to be the finale, and I quote from an email that I received from Craig in June of 2016 as the authority, "The Expeditionary Force series has ten books mapped out. The last two chapters of the tenth book has (sic) already been written..." Still, I enjoyed book 11, mostly, and look forward to #12. Will it be the last, I wonder?
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on January 7, 2021

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I can't understand how one person can keep churning out so many great books. The stories are not only some of, if not the, most entertaining titles I've ever read. They're FUN to read! I never had any idea how closely I could relate to a science fiction story in space, but this one is set in current times with 'regular' people, trying desperately to understand and utilize the unprecedented technology they've been tossed into. The author explains the science and technology in a very understandable way without getting lost in endless detail, partly because the protagonist is just a common Joe who needs things dumbed down for him. And so FUNNY! This author is probably the most sheerly entertaining that I've ever read. The only truly bad thing about the books in the Expeditionary Force series is getting to the end of the last one and waiting for the next to be released. Well, that and that one awful audio book in the series. I couldn't stomach listening to it. But fortunately the subsequent books did a decent job of synopsizing what happened in that one. I can't recommend this book series highly enough.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 12, 2022

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Another great addition, always love the humor
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This is a excellent series and has always been had well developed characters and spot on verbal interplay, the SciFi is just a bonus. Please keep it that way, mathmatical formulae and astrophysics already have books and those can be read just before bed to ensure a quick transition to sleep. Craig has nailed the verbal sparring/ interaction that help makes the military tolerable to the enlisted. This is coming from someone who served 11 years in two different branches of the armed forces. Yes, I was dumb enough to do it twice, yes you should thank your lucky stars that someone is, because you can still read this book at home safely. No I wouldn't go back and change a thing, end monolgue.To the author, keep at it your freakin' killin' it. I love the characters, the sass, their interplay and especially the sarcasm, bc without it, life would suck and we would be stuck with mathmatical formulae and theory. The story and plot are solid, but not super important to me, because I have seen great ideas suck via poor writing/ characters/ interplay. Your work has now become a common reference amongst my entire family (also the extended) and we all truly look forward to the next release.

bookDescription: When Sergeant Henry Morgan died and awoke a century later as the 'governing AI' for a starship......he didn't expect this.A darkness is spreading across the stars - and not just any darkness. This is a hyper-advanced, cancerous darkness named Corthaur, who was originally thought to be a pretty okay guy.He is not an okay guy.As the governing mind of humanity's first interstellar military starship, Henry just wants to help.But so much stands in his way.There's his AI-hating captain, for starters, who has severely limited the functions Henry can access.There's Corthaur, obviously, threatening to annihilate all life because he's just that bitter.And then there's the fact that a single star system stands in the way of Earth and total destruction.A system that's about to fall under brutal attack.The same system, as it happens, that Henry and his crew are about to show up in.Download I, Starship: Tin Can Combat now and grab the edge of your seat for this bold new space opera.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: What a trip! In a series like this, it's difficult not to have, if not an emotional connection, certainly an empathetic one with the main character. If I had the choice in these circumstances, I think I would make different choices. But, I live in reality, Earth-bound with no practical grasp of the choices afforded the humans in this Sci-Fi 'Space Opera' by author Scott Bartlett. If you enjoy expanding your imagination, any book by Scott Bartlett will do the trick, and 'Tin Can Combat' definitely will. -Mr.Bill
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 21, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Last stand of the Tin can sailors
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Your story felt familiar. As a follower of Naval history, I found your story remarkably similar to the true non-fiction story about Taffy 3 and the battle off Samar.  Right down to the makeup of the battle group and Bull Halseys battle group being lured away by a decoy. You really dug deep here.  It even depicted the incredible last stand of the USS Johnston and Commander Ernest E. Evans.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Poor Henry. What does a bot have to do to be noticed and/appreciated around here? Helping Captain Seemey fighting the Scree didn't endear himself like he hoped. Being bestowed with the Codex from Polyhistor seemed to anger the Captain, just because.....well, Henry just had to deal with it. But Captain Seemey would really go crazy if he found out Henry, and only Henry, had been given the key to access the Codex by Polyhistor.The Interchange was a formidable ship, but needed repairs before leaving the Toliman System, and Henry was filled with joy that he could help. He was sure, though, no one would appreciate this, either.The 2nd book in the "I, Starship: A Space Opera" book, picks up right after the 1st. The pace is fast and furious. This book grabs your attention in a way that makes it hard to put down. Scott Bartlett has a knack for keeping his readers on the edge of their seats, so carve out time to read this book. It's totally worth it!
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2024

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: It seems that sergeant Morgan's dialogue gets in the way of the story.  Dialogue seems kind of stilted no matter who is talking, but attempting to keep Morgan acting like a newbie gets in the way.  He seems so brainless for a combat veteran with a rank of sergeant.  I'd expect him to quickly use the simulator to make himself indispensable.  Also, what happened to Campbell?  I would have expected her to bring some reason into the story to counter the captain, but she goes off the rails, and starts taking attitude, and being disrespectful.  The story is improved, but we've diverted away from the original concept that the story is about the sergeant Henry Morgan.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 30, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Out of the frying pan (as they say!)
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Marine sergeant Henry Morgan wakes one day to discover that he's now a disembodied, electronically reconstituted mind controlling many of the functions of a huge starship. He still thinks and feels Human, but must come to grips with his new reality. Despite being treated as just a machine by the captain and crew, Henry manages to help save the day as they overcome impossible odds to defeat an enemy alien vessel that has wiped out another alien civilization, who bestow on Henry a cache of knowledge that only he can access.Now the starship continues to seek others threatened by the same enemy, and together with new allies must face what appears to be certain annihilation.Will Sergeant Morgan be able to help? And will he even be allowed to??
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2024

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I like the way the author uses a Marine soldier who died in an accident, was placed in cryogenic sleep, then almost one hundred years later, revive his brain and incorporates its memories into electronic data in a â€œblack boxâ€ type storage device.  All this because Earth has noticed alarming activity out in the stars.  Humanity has built the first and most advanced spacecraft ever built to investigate and hopefully stop the systematic destruction noted out by Alpha Centuri. The trip will take in excess is 82 years requiring the crew to go into cryo sleep on a 10 year rotational basis. They need a â€œhumanâ€ mind that can think out of the box (no pun intended) and not tire.  AIâ€™s canâ€™t.  They can only do as they are programmed.  Sounds great!  But no.  The captain hates AIâ€™s. Others have put an AI inline to monitor and restrict Henry.  What can go wrong?!There is drama, strife, hopelessness, loss and a whole gamut of issues form the crew and Henry.  I really like how the author humanizes Henry, including how can a human mind remain sane in an environment where there is no sleep, no one to talk to due to the crew in cryo, other than a â€œby the book, unyielding AI that canâ€™t recognize serious issues!Sorry for being long winded.  In shortâ€¦ this is a good book to read!  Enjoy it!

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Nice Visit But Not Enough Advancement
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Having put the galaxy in a state of Mutually Assured Destruction atthe end of the last book, Joe Bishop (and the whole of Earth) find thatbeing, finally, an acknowledged player on the galactic board is still nobed of roses.  In particular, both of the galaxy's opposing senior specieshave united to discourage any of their patrons from giving Earth the timeof day, and the Awful Kitties have gone so far as to launch a gas cloudfrom Jupiter to occlude the sun and throw Earth into an Ice Age, gamblingthat it won't be enough to get the humans to push the "destroy everything"button, and that since they have no other options with their fourth tiertechnology, they will look like losers, totally cutting off the chancesof them pulling any clients away.As usual, after much angst, Joe has an idea -- and it will mean,oddly, messing with the nicest of the aliens...I enjoyed this entry well enough, but if the idea is to end the war,something Emily Perkins proposed several books ago, the setup is takingquite a while, and in some respects this feels like another "middle" book.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: A sumptuous meal with a burnt dessert.
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: Book 12 is a rollercoaster ride with the usual Skippy comedy and the technical rabbit out of the hat solutions by Bishop. The Skippy jokes continue to be funny though are a little repetitive. It might have been better to have actual situation comedy rather than just hints. The drama of escaping the apex species onslaught is riveting and I am quite amazed at the plot brilliance. But there is a big BUT over here. This is book 12 out of a series of 12. Surely the ending could have been grander and fulfilling. Only one aspect of the book's plot is given closure. The eventual fate of the central character is just ignored and the ending is a failed attempt at tragi comedy involving side characters whose adventure is only beginning but snuffed due to the author's hurry to close the book. There is no sense of satisfaction of the 'happily ever after' syndrome because of so many loose ends. That is why I have likened it to a sumptuous meal with a burnt pudding. The end is clustered and doesn't do justice to such a long and enduring series. I strongly suggest that the author do a triology in which he shows how humanity achieves the apex status, the side characters violent ending is not only shelved but their goals are achieved and the central non human character whose existence makes the book possible reaches the fate he has aimed for since the beginning. If not then the author runs the risk of downgrading his own series himself.

The 12th novel in the Expeditionary Force series by Craig Alanson is titled "Breakaway" and humanity despite having galactic scale weapons of mass destruction have been easily maneuvered into a very bad position by the senior species of the galaxy, races that have had millenia to perfect their craft. The Maxolhx having engineered the approaching global ice age that is currently affecting the Earth and by extension vastly increasing the threat of humanity turning on itself are maybe a little too complacent as Joe Bishop, Skippy and the rest of the Pirates do their best work when forced into a corner and once again we see imaginative and intelligent scifi story telling which allows our heroes not to be swept aside. Not only that the Mavericks and Colonel Emily Perkins having been fully absorbed into the main narrative and are working their own military magic to strengthen the position of Earth and weaken the two main coalitions that control the galaxy. This novel really hit the ground running and never let up, good scifi story telling with strong characters both new and old and alien races which have purpose and add greatly the whole. Personally I loved the Jeraptha and their Ethics and Compliance Office but we also get more of the apex species interaction with humanity and other races which was very satisfying. Breakaway was an excellent read, loved it, love the series and well up for the next novel.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: Like the story, hate the egregious amount of technical errors
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: I've read all the previous books, so I'm locked into the series. I like the world (mostly), but my god there are so many typos, sentences with nonsensical commas in them, time where characters don't use contractions that make sentences feel awkward and not realistic, sentences that were very clearly edited but now make no sense, and sentences or paragraphs that repeat the same info, but with different wording. Also, some of the chapter breaks just make no sense, they just cut off in the middle of a scene, and then continue that scene with no time having passed.Overall, it feels like this is an early draft, where the story overall is solid, but there's still a bunch of stuff that needed work that just didn't happen. It feels like nobody did a final pass to correct for all these errors. I thought the author hired an editor? It sure doesn't seem like it with this book. I get that it's self-published, but the earlier books in the series had far less mistakes like this, but it's been growing over time. Book 15 was had a fair amount of errors, but it wasn't quite this bad.

I have loved this series since it started. When the story arc of the first 15 books ended, I was sad it had come to an end, but very glad I'd taken the ride on Craig Alanson's imagination and writing. His announcement that he had another five books in mind boosted my moral immensely, and #16 has exceeded my expectations. Sort of - I trusted Craig's awesomeness, and just like Skippy, he delivered. Reader's who've read the series will know what I mean.For those who haven't read it yet, strap in for one of the best romps of adventure, pathos, and fun (especially the blowing up stuff parts ;) ) you will ever read. Aliens invade the Earth, and humans are drug into a millenium long war, needing to find a way to survive. The universe discovers it it not prepared for what us monkey's can do, especially when we're assisted by the last viable AI of the elder race.The aliens are alien, but relatable. The main characters, even the bad guys, are realistic and grow with time. The plot twists keep it fresh and exciting. Craig's writing style will take you on a roller coaster ride of tension, ups and down all over the emotional spectrum, and the humour on nearly every page will have you laughing so hard and loud, people around you will wonder if you're in your right mind. If you're reading the series, you are.Yes, you have to start with book 1 (Columbus Day), but once you start, you'll be hooked. Just Trust the Awesomeness.

bookDescription: The man known as Cheradenine Zakalwe was one of Special Circumstances' foremost agents, changing the destiny of planets to suit the Culture through intrigue, dirty tricks and military action.The woman known as Diziet Sma had plucked him from obscurity and pushed him towards his present eminence, but despite all their dealings she did not know him as well as she thought.The drone known as Skaffen-Amtiskaw knew both of these people. It had once saved the woman's life by massacring her attackers in a particularly bloody manner. It believed the man to be a lost cause. But not even its machine could see the horrors in his past. Ferociously intelligent, both witty and horrific, USE OF WEAPONS is a masterpiece of science fiction.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Having just finished reading this novel for the second time, after the first time about 25 years ago, Iâ€™m revising my stars from 5 to 4 because, while the novel is very well constructed, it is also a difficult read. It took me several weeks to slog through the first 90% of the book. It was just very difficult to follow what was going on, and how the several scenes and storylines were related. 25 years ago, when I first read this novel, I was in college and I was actually a English major and maybe back then I was more available and open to this kind of dense literature. But now in my mid-50s, maybe Iâ€™m just tired of having to work so hard. The conclusion is the apex of the story, and thatâ€™s what I have remembered about this book for 25 years. But the twist â€” and hereâ€™s a spoiler â€” that our narrator is unreliable, I do not remember from 25 years ago. So that was a nice surprise, and made me want to go back and read the whole damn story again to find out if there were clues to this twist, and also to revisit the alternating chapters to see if I can find out who is the real protagonist.So, while the story is extremely intriguing and dense, I just donâ€™t think I have the time and energy left in my days to slog back through this novel yet again and actually do the investigation that this powerful story warrants. I shall, perhaps, do some web research to see if others have already done the digging for me.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on May 30, 2019

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: The Snark was a Boojum. So what?!
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Oh, Noes! Drizzle (I canâ€™t pronounce and refuse to spell her actual name) must be interrupted in her role as The Kardashian Who Arranges Peace Conferences, and even has to cut short her seduction of a pale, hip, new Artist, because She is The Only One who can convince Zalkawe (or something like that) to help, and Zalkawe is The Only One who can convince whatzisface (I completely give up) to help, and watzis is The Only One who can, by power of sheer inner moral persuasion, convince an entire star cluster from having itself a nice religious-ish interstellar war.Poor Drizzle. She even has to leave behind her cute little space bunnies. (I swear I am not making that up.) But not to worry, her instantly-created double, with all her memories, will take care of them. And fill in as The Kardashian Who etc. But no sex for the double, because Drizzle is a spoilsport.If youâ€™re wondering why they are The Only Ones, forget it. No explanation in the book that I could fathom. Thatâ€™s just a skyhook on which to hang a bunch of fairly inventive and actually enjoyable adventure fiction that is presented in two separate streams: Space adventure in Drizzleâ€™s universe of the Culture, with its 30-kilomeer superintelligent and hyperpowerful spaceships, as Drizzle finds Zalkawe and leaves wide open the question why he was supposedly so hard to convince; and a second thread of roughly WWI/WWII-technology war fiction, with some incongruous but fun elements, in the Zalkawe thread and the part after finding watzisface, which also leaves wide open the question of why watzis was so hard to convince.The two threads run in alternating chapters, with the old-timey (â€œprimitiveâ€) ones numbered in roman numerals, running backwards, which those old-time episodes also do in time. (Iâ€™ve heard people complain that they were confused by this. I strongly advise them to grow another brain cell.)The two streams roughly meet in time at the conclusion. At that point, an ultimate, universe-shattering, plot-destroying, non sequitur occurs, the source of my title. Unfortunately, that will have to remain unexplained here, since to talk about it would be a MAJOR SPOILER and Iâ€™m not into writing those.I originally picked up this book because it was recommended by China MiÃ©ville, a wonderful fantasy author (Read!! â€œPerdido Street Stationâ€ Read!!) who also happens to be an avowed and active Socialist. He recommended it as a depiction of a perfect socialist state, obviously referring to the Culture. I had no idea what that could mean, so I got the book. All I can say is: Well, China, I guess so. There are passages in which Zalkawe has the Culture explained to him. The only thing standing out to me is this: Despite how meaningful peopleâ€™s actions are said to be to them, I end up not seeing much use for humans in the Culture. Theyâ€™re all just Kardashians. Or Kardashian wanna-beâ€™s.Actually, Iâ€™m personally starting to have a hard time finding much use for Banks. His books just seem very interesting in the title, jacket, promo material, etc., but for me they regularly disappoint, just seemingâ€¦ bland. Suburbia in space. I find more sense of wonder, of strangeness, in one page of, say, Alastair Reynolds than in all 500+ pages of â€œUse of Weapons.â€ â€Inceptionâ€ came close, I will admit, until near the very end when, as in â€œUse of Weapons,â€ the entire point turned into something bland and/or just incomprehensible.But never the less, the middle 300+ pages of â€œUse of Weaponsâ€ are an easy read with some rollicking adventure, as they say, so enjoy as you will. Just donâ€™t expect any real consistency or motivation. I never felt bored; just disappointed.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on March 30, 2013

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Not really a Culture book, but a great story nonetheless
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Very few times do I put a book down and then exclaim "that was deep".  Well, this was one of those few time.  I read UofW years ago, and I re-read it a few months back, and now I can say that the re-read (and knowing in advance how it ends) brings out another measure of depth that previously went unnoticed.Above all, it is a very carefully written book. It is crafted to have the reader continue to guess after each chapter about the outcome of the story as well as the origin of the main character (Zakalwe). This practice, at times is stressful, because Banks is very good at misleading the reader and even at time purposefully confusing us just to build up the suspense for another upcoming chapter.  Several others have mentioned the forward and reverse timelines, and while I see why this story was told in this unique fashion, I also realize that Banks is not fully transparent in the reverse timeline. In fact, at one point, Banks jumps from one 3rd person viewpoint to another, and he does so in a fashion that is both abrupt and discordant, but by the time this happens you (at least I didn't), don't care because by then you are fully committed to finding out why Zakalwe tortures himself for the sake of a micro-managing galactic civilization which he holds in some disdain.Forward or reverse, it doesn't matter, when it boils down this is pretty much the story of Zakalwe: his life, his philosophy and his numbing/excruciating pursuit of his one and only goal. The Culture in this story, represented by a drone and Diziet S'ma, (who is a major character in another Culture novella "State of the Art") function mostly as facilitators and enablers for Zakalwe. Unlike other Culture novels, where a specific concept within the Culture is explored or even some policy decision within Contact or Special Circumstance is brought to question, here you get none of that. While it is a bit of false advertising, trust me, it won't matter.  The story has such a powerful message and such a Shyamalan-like ending that you almost forget that it is set in the Culture universe.There also seems to be an agreement, that UofW ends in a cliffhanger. I don't think that is true. Re-reading the whole book and then carefully reading the prologue and epilogue (in that order) explains exactly what happens to Zakalwe. A great story which also provides adequate closure, what more can you want?...maybe 5+ star rating.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2017

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: outstanding sci-fi horror from the master
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: One of Banksâ€™s best and arguably most challenging novels from the Culture series. Two parallel plot-lines each containing intricate details about cleverly drawn characters in brilliantly rendered narrative eventually collide in a stunning denouement. Banks probes the motivations that drive generals to win wars at any cost and the impact on their personal lives and also the lives of those affected by their decisions. The novel bridges the genres of sci-fi and horror with exquisite skill to create a story that is as disturbing as it is engaging.
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 17, 2023

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: So angry at the book I read it all over again
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: The first book that left me speechless at the end, raging against the author, the main character, everyone... I immediately had to read it again.So yeah, for being the first book that got me to read it twice in a row, 5 stars. Read it. You'll either hate it or love it. And pay attention to the numbering of the chapter - one timeline moves forward, the other back.

The unlikely winner of the Banks oeuvre. To me atleast.Just plough past the confusion created by the structure of the book and the sometimes self indulgent reveries and you will find yourself reading a gripping story about a flawed military genius who does everything, and absolutely anything, to win a fight.
Fantastic sci-fi

Una de las mejores novelas de Iain M banks pertenecientes a La Cultura.Emocionante,original y llena de suspense.El final es sorprendente.Banks otorga a esta novela un estilo muy literario jugando con los narradores,el punto de vista y la cronologia de los hechos.Altamente recomendable.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: A Riveting Prelude to Galactic Conflict
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: In the vast expanse of science fiction literature, few works stand as tall and as influential as *Horus Rising* by Dan Abnett. This novel, the opening salvo in the epic *Horus Heresy* series, is nothing short of a masterpiece, deserving of every one of its five stars.From the moment readers dive into the pages of *Horus Rising*, they are transported to a universe teetering on the brink of cataclysmic conflict. Set in the grim darkness of the far future, the novel introduces us to the sprawling empire of the Imperium of Man, ruled by the enigmatic God-Emperor and beset by threats from within and without.At the heart of the story lies the primarch Horus, beloved by his brothers and revered by his legion of Space Marines. As Warmaster of the Imperium, Horus is tasked with leading humanity's crusade to conquer the galaxy in the name of the Emperor. But as tensions simmer and betrayals brew, Horus finds himself torn between loyalty to his father and the seeds of rebellion sown by dark forces.One of the greatest strengths of *Horus Rising* is its rich and immersive world-building. Abnett effortlessly brings to life a universe brimming with detail, from the war-torn battlefields of distant planets to the labyrinthine corridors of the Imperial Palace. Every aspect of the setting feels meticulously crafted and authentic, drawing readers deeper into the story with each turn of the page.But perhaps the true triumph of *Horus Rising* lies in its characters. From the noble warriors of the Adeptus Astartes to the scheming politicians of the Imperium, each character is rendered with depth, complexity, and nuance. Horus himself is a particularly compelling figure, a hero torn between duty and ambition, grappling with the weight of his destiny and the whispers of darkness that threaten to consume him.Abnett's prose is equally impressive, combining visceral action with introspective moments of reflection to create a narrative that is as gripping as it is thought-provoking. The dialogue crackles with wit and tension, driving the plot forward at a relentless pace while also providing insight into the minds of the characters.In conclusion, *Horus Rising* is a tour de force of science fiction storytelling that deserves its place among the genre's greatest works. With its epic scope, richly drawn characters, and masterful prose, it is a novel that will linger in the minds of readers long after they have turned the final page. Whether you're a die-hard fan of the Warhammer 40,000 universe or simply someone looking for a gripping tale of heroism and betrayal, *Horus Rising* is not to be missed.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on March 3, 2024

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This is a great start to an amazing series based on the Warhammer universe.  The character development is very engaging, and the world settings are rich and emersive, giving a very enjoyable juxtaposition to reality, allowing the reader to completely engage with the story.This is a violent setting and may not be suitable for readers under the age of seventeen.  There are no explicit scenes and no foul language, though. Instead, the author develops the story using classical literary writing techniques that are a breath of fresh air in this age of pop fiction.I would strongly recommend this book, and I look forward to continuing this epic adventure.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: â€œI was there the day Horus slew the Emperor.â€ â€“ A Riveting Tale of Ambition and Betrayal
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: As someone new to Warhammer 40,000, I approached Horus Rising with hesitation. Could a novel about genetically engineered super-soldiers in a dystopian future hold my interest? Dan Abnettâ€™s gripping storytelling turned that question into an emphatic yes.The story follows Horus, the Emperor of Mankindâ€™s chosen Warmaster, as he leads the Great Crusade to unify humanity. Told through the eyes of Captain Garviel Loken, the book explores the camaraderie, moral dilemmas, and cracks forming within the Imperiumâ€™s seemingly perfect vision.What surprised me most was how personal the narrative felt. Despite the epic battles and vast scope, the characters â€“ especially Horus and Loken â€“ are richly human. Horus is both inspiring and flawed, burdened by immense responsibility, while Lokenâ€™s introspection and growing doubts make him a compelling guide through this universe.Abnettâ€™s worldbuilding is immersive yet accessible, striking a balance that welcomes newcomers without overwhelming them. The grim, gothic atmosphere of starships and the philosophical debates surrounding the Emperorâ€™s secular vision add depth to the action. The battles themselves are brutal but purposeful, advancing both the story and the charactersâ€™ arcs.Themes of loyalty, faith, and ambition resonate powerfully, making the book more than just military sci-fi. Itâ€™s a tale of humanityâ€™s fragility and the cost of idealism.For newcomers, Horus Rising offers a thrilling, approachable entry point into Warhammer 40,000. Itâ€™s a story of epic scale grounded in intimate, relatable struggles. By the end, I was captivated and eager to see how the haunting opening line â€“ â€œI was there the day Horus slew the Emperorâ€ â€“ would unfold.A must-read for anyone who loves stories of ambition, betrayal, and the weight of destiny.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: Excellent read, for ALL sci-fi fans
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: I'm over 50, and I've only ever played a few dozen games of Warhammer in my entire life, and all those games were in the late 80's when I was gifted 'space hulk' for a birthday. The game was lost in a house move a couple of years later, and that was that!What I'm getting at is I'm no gamer and I've not attempted to paint a miniature since my Genestealers and Blood Angels from 'Space Hulk' were physically assaulted by my paint brush as a teenager.However, what I do like is science fiction, both film and novels, especially when a great deal of time, thought and effort has been invested in the lore around that particular universe, e.g. Star-trek and Warhammer 40K.I'd been looking for something to read recently as I'd been off work with an injured back and I came across the HH set of books online. I did about 60 mins of wiki reading to get the bare bones and thought I'd give the first book a go.You know you're onto a winner when you sit up waaay past bed time, saying "one more paragraph, ok just this chapter" 4 nights in a row. Yep....4 days and I'm a slow reader who likes to keep checking the index to keep up with who is who, however, I need not have worried as the myriad of character names are repeated often enough for them to sink in, which going into the book was my biggest concern.My second concern was, did I know enough basics? and the hour on Wiki was more than enough, as the author pitched the book just right, telling the story, and injecting the appropriate amount of historical reference where necessary, and it had me gripped.Abnett's  descriptions of fight scenes are excellent, but one thing I didn't expect, which was a massive bonus, was the amount of humour in the book, and this is where Abnett excels in character building.I'm not going to bang on about the contents, I'll leave that to the experts, I'm here to convince those like me that it's not a heavy book, it's very enjoyable and entertaining and I've downloaded books 2&3 already!Enjoy!Jon  (hubby to firechick)
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on April 2, 2024

bookDescription:
Siege of Terra, Book 2
The Solar War is over. The Siege of Terra has begun. As the Traitors unleash their deadliest weapons, the defenders of the Throneworld face nightmare and plague - but Terra must stand.
Listen to it because: discover the lengths to which Horus will go to claim Terra as his own - and the horrors he is willing to set upon its defenders.
The story: on the 13th day of Secundus, the bombardment of Terra began. With the solar defences overcome through the devastating strength of the Traitor armada and the power of the warp, Horus launches his assault on the Throneworld in earnest. After withstanding a ferocious barrage of ordnance, an immense ground war commences outside the Palace, with every inch gained paid for in the lives of billions. The front lines are beyond horrific, and the very air is reduced to poison and blood. Bodies are thrown into the meat grinder, but the outer redoubts cannot possibly hold for long, even with the loyal primarchs to reinforce them.
For Horus has his own generals to call upon. Between the plague weapons of Mortarion and the fury of Angron, the defenders face a losing battle.
Written by Guy Haley. Narrated by Jonathan Keeble.

productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2020

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: This books shows the epic drama of Warhammer from an interesting perspective: the scared Soldier
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: It's my belief to write on certain subjects in Warhammer 40K, you must be one of the golden children. They won't simply select a little-known author or relative nobody; like the Primarch series, the Black Library bends its most talented wordsmiths to the task and expects the very best in results.This book is a prime example of that. Every situation, every encounter, every plotline brings you to the room almost as if you were living these times of crisis. You feel the sadness of Sanguinus, the hatred of Mortarion, the fear of Imperial citizens, the foolishness of the lost and the damned; you whoop for joy when the Khan rides, rememer your own fond moments when Sanguinus appears and feel the sadness of potential destroyed when Horus is on the page.The books shows a hideous, awful side of war that so many Warhammer books touch upon but so few bring to life; the misery of the Imperial citizen caught in a battle of titans. Here, though, it's worse; this is betrayal as it happens, the realization that not even the very best of us can resist temptation and ego.Another reviewer - Kid Kyoto - whines and sniffles about the pace of the book. I promise that you will not be bored; in fact, each subplot strengthens the story and keeps you in suspense as each grand plan of attacker and defender comes to light.This book is hard to put down, and it will be one you will not regret reading.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: El producto es tal y como se muestra, viene MUY BIEN protegido, ya que no sÃ³lo se encuentra en la bolsa de burbujas en la que normalmente son enviadas, tambiÃ©n estÃ¡ en una bolsa de plÃ¡stico que protege el producto aÃºn mejor.
Buona scrittura, migliore per ora del primo capitolo, fin troppo incentrato sulla guerra nello spazio.

This book was solid like the "Solar War". It details the bombardment from Horus' fleet as well as the first traitor landings on Terra's soil. The emphasis is placed on the conscripts which is good as we get to see how they are forced to defend their homes from unimaginable horrors. However, there were some aspects of the book that brought down the narrative.Spoilers below for the book.First with the negatives:Black Library editors somehow missed the fact that Dorn met with Vulcan near the end of Nick Kyme's "Old Earth" novel when the latter arrived on Terra. Somehow, this was retconned out of existence and Dorn is surprised along with his other brother primarchs when Malcador reveals Vulcan is alive during the war council meeting at the beginning of the story. I could not help but roll my eyes.I thought Perturabo's outbursts to be unbecoming for the famed Lord of Iron. Sure, the primarchs do act like children but Perturabo usually has a lot of restraint and here he comes across as a spoiled brat. However, his banter with Angron was entertaining.Myzmadra's arc was brought to a bit of a disappointing end with her whole undercover operation meant to blow a defence Bastion of the loyalists to let the traitors through. Ok...The stare down between Angron and Sanguinius near the end was a bit unnecessary because it is a tease that this particular primarch v. primarch duel will happen in future books. Except it is more entertaining when there are no teases and when the moment comes, it is sudden and a welcome surprise.Positives:Gendor Skraivok getting destroyed by Raldoron was one of the most satisfying things I have seen in the entire Horus Heresy series. It was pretty nasty seeing how Skraivok got possessed by the demon of the sword however.The three loyal primarchs each shine in this book despite their minimal page time with Dorn coordinating the defences, Sanguinuis providing hope for the defenders, and the Khan riding out like a boss. I especially liked how Sanguinius saved the Khan from the Death Guard and the mutual respect forming between these two demigods.The conscript Katsuhiro was a relatable character and his arc was good even though he had a bit too much plot armour.The tragedy of the Heresy is seen very clearly with the appearances of the World Eaters and Death Guard who have by this point gone off the deep end in their slavery to their patron gods. Even Horus himself is but a shadow of his former self which Abaddon greatly dislikes.
Geile epische Geschichte.

bookDescription:
The Rebellion against Earth expands to new worlds.
Left to die on a volcanic world by the Skrull, McGill and his mercenaries face waves of missile attacks with nowhere to hide. When the Skrull seal themselves inside an impenetrable energy dome, McGill knows he has to get creative. Even if that means sabotaging alien power plants, blackmailing his superior officers, and using his own troops as bait in a deadly game of cat and mouse.
But the real enemy isn't the dome, or even the Rebel Blue Skrull forces trying to overrun the planet. It's McGill's commanding officers, who are looking for any excuse to execute him for insubordination. Now McGill has to pull off his riskiest gambit yetâ€”turning certain defeat into victory while staying just barely on the right side of mutiny.
Rage World is the latest action-packed entry in B.V. Larson's bestselling Undying Mercenaries series.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Jaxon Reed understands "space operas"--great diversions from life's cares
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: The Farmer series was just a wonderful series of escapades.  "High Tech"; AI; furious beastly predators; evil scheming villains; heroic good guys; some PG romance; miracles that "save the day"--it had it all.SO...with proven capability in his art and his audience, the author expands his story and his core themes with flare and competence.  Old friends resurface; new allies are found; loaded with "PEW PEW PEW" battles; hints of BIG THINGS SIMMERING--just a fun romp.  It's a quick and easy read, and it held my attention until the end.  If you want deep thinking, explorations of philosophy, evocative/profound description, etc, then go read War and Peace [I dare you to finish it; I didn't].  But to "get away from it all" and KNOWING that truth and justice and honor will always win in the end, you can't go wrong with this.  Eagerly awaiting the next book in series.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Another great start to a new series
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Picking up shortly after the end of System Alignment, we are reintroduced to Bo Duckworth as he deals with the fallout of doing the right thing. Arriving at Athos station where he expects to work as a miner, he encounters two Phaethon Corp employees and joins in their adventure.Mr. Reed is off to another great start with this new series, full of running firefights, chutes and ladders style hollowed out asteroids, and the sly humor present in the previous Milky Way books. There are some fantasy elements here too, with the outer space version of Imps, Ogres, and Trolls making an appearance. Some well placed appearances by Tom Savage help tie everything together.This is a really fun read and I'm looking forward to the rest of the series.

bookDescription: The Emperor's daughters are coming to the Frontier...with an illegally seized warfleet for unknown purposes. They are raiding for supplies, or receiving them from sympathizers as they cut a path across the Empire encouraging all who will listen to rise up and overthrow their father. Whether they be allies, enemies, or something else is unclear, but the Emperor has loaned a large Mainline Fleet to Aatroxiss for him to use to stop them if the Imperial Fleet cannot, and with so many traitors in their midst, it looks like Visha and Victa will make it to the distant Frontier within approximately two years of their public rebellion. Grand Admiral Aatroxiss knows better than to let them get into the Frontier, so he waits for them to get close to the border then takes High Admiral Greganin's fleet out to confront them. No matter how this goes down, it will reshape the political landscape within the Empire permanently, and with rising tensions amongst the lesser Dynasties, the word being floated in the public discourse more and more is one no one wants to hear. productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Some Years You Can't Get A Break
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Archer Devereaux can't get a break.  An up & coming young navalofficer in the Phlegraean fleet, his career took a nose dive whenhe was found sleeping with the wife of his commanding officer.  Hehad no idea who she was, and that in fact she had specially pickedhim out because she was furious at her husband (it turned out sheactually liked Devereaux, so she was sorry about it, but damagedone).  The fleet is not particularly puritan, and everything wasconsensual and out of the chain of command, so Arch was cleared,officially.  Unofficially, his name was mud, especially with Academygraduates.The outbreak of war, and his ongoing success in battle, along withthe turnover of war-revealed dead-wood in the Admiralty ranks seemto have Devereaux's star on the rise again, but somehow he keepsgetting assigned to diplomatic missions which always end in bloodand disorder for some (as yet mysterious) reason.These are very straight-forward, low-key "He did this, and then hedid that" books which work better in that presentation than youmight think.  The battles are low-key as well.  Ships are veryexpensive and it is uncommon to have more than three on each sideengaging.  Space is also large, so there is a lot of hunt & seekwith weeks between engagements, and people are people, so there isalways backbiting and corruption in high places.  There is also onewoman who keeps turning up in all of Arch's troubles (sometimesseemingly as the cause of them), and she may be The One, though,as I said, it's a pretty casual setting, and Arch manages to findother friendly companionship (with benefits) along the way.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: But the space navy battles lack some essential details. Thereâ€™s never any issues with detecting enemy ships. In fact thereâ€™s no mention of how ships are detected at all. Thereâ€™s no real question of communications, or emissions control. Drones can explode on or near ships. Why arenâ€™t the drones carrying nuclear warheads? Why arenâ€™t they using nuclear bomb pumped laser fire?Everyone has FTL communications nearly all the time. It seems to me that would allow headquarters to micromanage operations, just as happens in our reality.Why did the fleet merger conference have about zero security? As soon as the details were revealed, I thought, â€œUt oh, thereâ€™s trouble.â€Computer security in the book is not as good as it was in the 1960s in the US. It seems like bad actors can do as they wish to computer systems without any problems.For a better example of the genre, read Chain of Command, by Frank Chadwick.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: By the Book or Buy the Book
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: My favorite book in the Horus Heresy series is Ben Counter's "Galaxy in Flames." The reason being that it gripped me and moved me. More often than not I have had a hard time identifying with the space marines. They seemed too god-like, too cold; just heart-less killing machines. Counter made me care about the marines.James Swallow's book "Flight of the Eisenstein" follows Counter's book and moves the plot forward. In many respects I found Swallow's book equal too and sometimes superior (a hard call)to "Galaxy in Flames."Some of the characters from the previous book re-appear and we see events from the earlier books played out from the point-of-view of members of the Death Guard.The protagonist of "Flight of Eisenstein is Battle-Captain of the 7th Company of the Death Guard--Nathaniel Garro. For the most part, we see the action through his pov, although Swallow breaks the unity from time to time to enter the minds of subordinate characters.The book begins with an attack on a Jorgall ship, where we see both the Death Guard and the Oblivion Knight, Amendera Kendel, in action. A psyker's warning of impending doom alerts the reader to treachery ahead and the action begins.The "Flight of the Eisenstein" shows us Horus's strategy becoming visible in the battles of the Isstvan sector. It also develops the rise of the new saint Euphrati Keeler.These plot points are important to the overall development of the series; however, Swallow has presented some interesting touches. The description of the ship's trip through the warp seemed particularly clear and cogent; the hatred of Grulgor was palpable and handled well;the infestation and contamination of Decius was logical and well-developed; the description of the Luna base was brilliant; and the conversion of Garro was believable.In summary, Swallow writes a clear serviceable prose that moves the story along. His fantastic descriptions are quite realistic. I found it a very satisfying novel.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2009

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: James Swallow takes up the fourth novel of the Horus Heresy series, which follows one of the pivotal historical events of Games Workshop's Warhammer 40,000 universe. This novel tells the tale of Battle-Captain Nathaniel Garro of the Death Guard, a minor character in the previous books, and at its core this is a tale of his personal growth and discovery, though action features heavily as well. He is cut of the same cloth as Captain Garviel of the Sons of Horus Legion and main protagonist from the first novels: able, principled, and introspective. Several Primarchs and historical characters make appearances, including: Horus, Rogal Dorn, Mortarion, Captain Typhon (Death Guard), Captain Tarvitz (Emperor's Children), Captain Sigismund (Imperial Fists), and others.I have been a vocal critic of M. Swallow's past works for the Black Library, which have been long on purple prose and dues ex machina, and short on background knowledge and plot, so I picked up this book with no small amount of trepidation. However, I must say that this is easily his best work and is a worthy successor to the other Horus Heresy books.The characters have depth, realistic motivations and reactions, and grow in ways that make sense. Particularly telling is Garro's development as he attempts to come to terms with the betrayal of his own Primarch and that of Horus. Without going into anything that would spoil the plot for others, let's just say that it's well doneThe action scenes flow well, and convey an excellent sense of urgency. The opponents don't make stupid mistakes for the sake of the plot - a weakness in M. Swallow's prior works. His descriptions of the Primarchs, particularly Mortarion, feel slightly mundane once or twice, but typically have the proper sense of awe. The ending of the book gives a tantalizing hint of things to come without being a tease.In short: a solid addition to the Horus Heresy series and a good read that you'll have trouble putting down.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on May 28, 2007

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: The flight of the Eisenstein and the birth of Heroes
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: What a pleasant surprise guys :OI must admit that I had no expectation regarding that book before reading. I had only been hearing miscellaneous reviews here and there : epic, dull, interesting, unnecessary.But my opinion is clear on the matter : the Flight of the Eisenstein is undeniably a high quality book. Admittedly, it's not as epic as the First Heretic, Betrayer or Horus Rising but it's almost every bit as good as them !James Swallow manages to steer the story in a very compelling way.We discover the great character named Nathaniel Garro. The only beacon of hope who can bring the news of Horus' betrayal to Terra.And most importantly, we learn to like him and to root for him.This book contains so much lore about the Death Guard legion : its customs, its ways, its fighting style, why the legionaries drink poison for breakfast, the internecine oppositions and their fall to chaos.In the face of sheer madness, appalling damnation and certain death stands Garro. Unyielding. Proud. Staunch. Loyal to his oath to mankind.The flight through the void is harsh, costly and exhausting but the reading is highly enjoyable and it will keep you hooked until the very last page !A legion falls, heroes rise and Primarchs get ready for an all-out conflict.If you wish to know more about the early stage of the Heresy then go get a copy of that book !Best regards guys :)

The destination is the Alpha Corvi system, where an allied warship has vanished. Alex can guess why.
Her fears prove trueâ€”Alpha Corvi is under new ownership. Alex must face the monsters from her childhood again as her regiment mounts a rescue operation to find and save the planetâ€™s colonists. But this time, there is something terrifyingly different about their enemy. The Corps has evolved to meet the threat, but the Lankies have adapted as wellâ€”and they are more lethal than ever. What began as a rescue turns into a desperate fight for survival for Alex and her new friends, stranded on a hostile world forty-nine light-years from Earth. And the only way home goes right through the Lankies.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: It is a follow-up of the life of Alex Archer and everything fits rather well in the Lankiverse: No big explanations about its but no hollow pew-pew either.The length is appropriated. It is basically auto-conclusive thouhg it lets the things rather open and in a good sense. All in all, this is perhaps one of the best books in the saga and it points to fresh developments that fit with the previous ones.Just one or two tiny details that rubbed me wrong. For instance, Alex keeps on calling "sir" to every sargent and NCO she founds and no one of them chews her out for that. And burbers and PRC do not mix but in the first books of the series they mixed basically OK...

bookDescription:
Mack Banes is the first face you want to see in the last place you'd want to beâ€¦
Wreck Jumpers are highly specialized soldiers trained for search and rescue deep behind enemy lines. They are the special forces operators sent in when things have already gone from bad to worse.
Malcolm "Mack" Baines and his Recovery Team are the best of the best. When a Special Orbital Assault Regiment School nestled inside an asteroid belt suddenly goes dark, Mack and his team of Wreck Jumpers are tasked with putting eyes on the target.
Their mission: recon the site and turn the comms back on.
What they find is a base in chaos with survivors desperately holding out for rescue amid oceans of floating rock and an unknown enemy determined to make the Wreck Jumpers part of a growing body count.
Just one wrong move could mean a crushing end in the cold vacuum of space and the death of everyone relying on Mack and his operatorsâ€¦
But that's why Mack became a Wreck Jumper in the first place.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: This is not your normal scifi...  this is Wreck Jumpers.... modeled after Para rescue.
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Wreck Jumpers.If you pick this up and have no idea of the Galaxy Edge universe, this is a great teaser to get ALL of them.  This book was modeled after some of the most unsung heroes who do not want the accolades, who do not want the fame.  ParaRescue(PR). Most military knows now that Doc, is ..DOC.  Doc must be protected at all costs, however, PR's bring a whole new level of kick ass to the field.  When the US Special Forces calls for medivac, PR comes in and kicks more ass than the SF kids, to get the wounded out and safe.Why is this important?  Why do I put an emphasis on this level of effort?  Ask a military friend you know.  PR are the guys who JUMP INTO the areas that are so hot the SF teams need an evac, they are the fearless, only GOD will stop them from succeeding at whatever mission is in front of them.  Black holes?  bah, trivial crap.  The enlisted are the key drivers of the REC-teams.  You want something done?  Give it to the First Sargent and tell him the teams can have the rest of the day off when finished.  You won't get the order completed before it's done. There is a constant in any military, the Senior Enlisted are the backbone, and the officers, if they are smart will listen to them.  Remember that as you read forward.I thought this would be a "Oh? crap broke? let's go get it and save folks and do some heroic stuff" type of read, maybe in the first few paragraphs but it takes that and expands it into the Galaxy Edge universe, it shows the growth and mentoring of the enlisted characters in intense situations and allows you to put a real voice into your head when you read the lines.  There is the new guy who has to earn his place and keep it, the old salt running the team, who feels like he has a PhD in warfighting. and the Officers, who have all built something that this type of team must have.  Implicit trust in the team, each other, and doing the right thing, even if it will cause problems.Standard military, cover your ass is one thing, but in this Universe it carries to a whole new level.I apply voices to each character as I read, a voice, an image and a manner of body language.  Fresher, the new guy has this just out of puberty voice in my head that still breaks when he gets excited.  Top (Mack) has a voice similar to a 80's Scifi TV show Admiral, and Creeper?  His voice is one of the pilots off that same series.  yeah, corny as hell but.. it's how I read.The story is enveloping, enticing and absolutely spot on for this Universe and fits into it like a glove.  For those of you reading this, and not familiar, it is a perfect intro to the Universe and a great lead into Dark Ops, Night Ops and the skills and absolute top tier abilities to go save those and prevent the enemy access to the good stuff.  If you enjoy Scifi, this is a Universe that Jason and Nick and many others over at Wargate spend all their time giving us the ability to escape from the day to day BS we deal with.If you have read into this Universe, gear up, get your get set and your L-comm set for a few hours of seamless matching and some hair raising rescues and plots.This book has some really awesome plot slides and twists, and will keep you in it  cover to cover.  Get into Wreck Jumpers and get to reading.

bookDescription: Brad Mendoza is an idiot. He knows it, and so does everyone else in the star nation of Prometheus. A promising naval career down the drain just because he accidentally killed 504 civilians. So, it's time for him to give up and accept a dead-end command on Persephone, the worst starship in the fleet. Until he meets the beautiful and cunning Jessica Lin, his new executive officer, who harbors a terrible secret of her own. Now, with an enemy warship four times their size bearing down on them, Brad's in a race to save Jessica and his stupid ship.But Brad Mendoza is an idiot. We'll just have to hope that he's the lucky kind.An exciting military sci-fi adventure and space opera thriller with plenty of twists, turns, and humor. This short novel kicks off a series of books in the exciting and fan-favorite universe of Dumb Luck and Dead Heroes. Order today!

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Fast paced action in space seen through a wry perspective.
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: A quick read, reminding me of The Murderbot Diaries (and this book only has a score more pages to go). The humour is with us from the start, seen through the self-deprecating MC, and the world building comes natural through dialogue and action (no info dumps). The book feels like the first one in a series, limning the cast who I hope weâ€™ll meet further down the page. I feel it deals with trauma in a somewhat cursory way, solving it logically, but not emotionally. And mind you, if you like to think out the solutions in the story (like in a murder mystery), this book isnâ€™t about that. The solutions they come up with are part of the world building so you canâ€™t know beforehand (but the solutions are plausible and rhymes with our world, so they are easy to buy, except for one time when it felt out of character, but that might explained when I read further).That said, itâ€™s well worth spending your time with if you want fast paced action seen through a wry perspective.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2024

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This is the first book I've read by Skyler Ramirez and I'm glad I found his work.  This first book was a refreshing read, light and funny and a fun adventure.  My only con first: it's short.  Weighing in at 137 pages, the first book is over quickly after the characters and world are established.  When I realized I was a third of the way through the book and I was still getting up to speed with the beginning of the main plot, I almost put it down.  But then I saw it was a series.  And that leads into the pros: It's an interesting world with interesting characters.  Brad Mendoza is a lovable self-destructive buffoon, with a past he hasnâ€™t come to terms with.  Heâ€™s funny and self-depreciating, and the running narrative from his jaded perspective keeps the story moving.  Jessica Lin comes off as a two dimensional Miss Perfect but I think the coming books will flesh out her character more.  Sheâ€™s got a past too, that will need to come to light.  Thereâ€™s just the right amount of world-building for a book this length and I canâ€™t wait to see what the rest of the series looks like.  And Iâ€™m hoping the antagonist from the first book ends up being the villain of the series.  Weâ€™ll see.  I highly recommend this if youâ€™re looking for a light, clean, funny space adventure.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Whereâ€™s the Sixth Star for Awesomeness!
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I happened upon this book somewhat by accident.  As a new author in the genre I made it a point to familiarize myself with other books like what I was writing. It checked the boxes of social proof with a high number of reviews and the blurb was intriguing. What I didnâ€™t expect was a wildly entertaining ride through the galaxy with Brad and Jessica, all orchestrated by Maestro Ramirez!The writing is great, the action is fast paced, but best of all, the humanity of the characters is what really shines through!  Skyler Ramirezâ€™s style is not what one typically expects in many genres nowadays: he proves that an author can write without any gratuitous language and violence, but yet keeps it real. Itâ€™s refreshing, actually.Iâ€™m writing this review as I read through the 8th of this series since I got so into them I forgot to pay it forward to highly endorse this series!  Itâ€™s not just this series too, so read everything else Skyler has written.  Donâ€™t be like Brad and go READ!

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: Hooks you in for a fast-paced adventure
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: I wasn't sure about this book at first, just from the blurb and details on Amazon, I tend to avoid the smaller books and go for longer ones that have some world building. But I gave this a chance, and I was immediately hooked, very short read, there's enough depth to the characters to get a sense on things and then it takes you on a whirlwind of an adventure. The story keeps building in the next book, and the one after (just starting the 4th now).I've not been able to put them down, enjoying the story, the flow, and the characters. Very entertaining reads that aren't over the top so it ends up being relaxing to read. Would highly recommend!

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: I've been an avid reader my entire adult life, since the 70s. In this day of self-publishing, there's a lot of bad writing out there now that in the past never would have made it to the press. A reader often has to wade through a lot of badly written slop before finding someone who can actually write well. So I'm very happy to have recently discovered Mr. Ramirez. He knows how to write and he delivers on the promise of his titles. It's light-hearted escapism, and very, very funny. And his writing skill is excellent, a pleasure to read. I will be reading the rest of the series.

I'm not overly enthusiastic about broken heroes and started the book a little reluctantly. What can I say. I read it in one go and was annoyed when someone tried to interrupt me. Yes, it is that entertaining and well written. If you are into space opera, have a go and enjoy yourself.I will definitely read the next book in the series. Like, right now.
Not entirely sure why I picked up this book. Upto 59% itâ€™s pure nonsense after which I skipped and went to rating the book.
This is a great read different from any sc fi I have read I loved the humor in this book make sure you read it .

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: The second book of the Horus Heresy series, this time penned by Graham McNeill, is a ripping adventure tale that continues the story of Horus' inevitable fall. Garviel Lorken, the Company Captain of the Sons of Horus Legion and main protagonist from the first novel, now shares the stage with Horus himself in roughly equal measure. The supporting cast is too numerous to list here, but suffice to say, it includes many other canonical characters from Games Workshop's Warhammer 40K universe: Horus, Angron, Fulgrim, Magnus, Kharn, Abaddon, Fabius, and others.M. McNeill does an excellent job capturing the feel of the 40K background, excels at action scenes, and captures the epic scope of the Crusade and subsequent Heresy. You really feel the ground tremor as titans stride into battle, and quail before Angron's savagery as he charges into the fray. The enemies of the Imperium fight intelligent campaigns that reflect well thought out strategy, making them worthy foes.Gone, however, is the subtlety and delicate moral quandary of M. Abnett. Lorken's character growth, and that of some of the other characters, takes a back seat to Horus' tale and larger-scale conflict. This brings me to the two weaker points of the novel:1 - M. McNeill uses some clumsy plot devices at key points in the work. The Mournival (Horus' council of Captains) and some of the senior Sons of Horus act stupidly or ignorantly from time to time, even though it's been firmly established that they are neither. There are a few other instances where Marines "regress" from extremely wily to easily misled.2 - The biggest difficulty, however, is in the representation of the change in Horus. There are no slippery moral slopes filled with the excuses of expediency or necessity. There is no gradual or subtle descent, such as those displayed by M. Abnett's Inquisitor Eisenhorn. Instead, Horus takes the Warp induced visions of a man he admittedly doesn't even trust, and makes a decision without even checking the veracity of these mirages. As it's really one of the pivotal moments of the entire epic, it's disappointing that it doesn't receive the attention it deserves.These - although fairly significant - detractors aside, the book is a very engaging read, and M. McNeill's writing style holds the reader's attention throughout. The plot flows well, and one can't wait to begin the next chapter after finishing the previous.In short: a generally solid work with a few troubles for more discerning readers. However, any fan of 40K will easily get his money's worth on this ride.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Compelling and disturbing - the quintessence of grimdark
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Like watching film of 9-11, or the attack on Pearl Harbor, or the start of World War I.  A haunting sense of imminent tragedy that we can see coming but cannot  avert.To be honest, before I read this book and Horus Rising I was not really looking forward to reading the Horus Heresy novels.  I thought I already knew the story, the characters would be flat caricatures, and much of the action would be like something out of a well-funded but completely derivative comic-book movie.  I have come to expect great things from Dan Abnett and Graham McNeill, but I feared that even writers with their talent would be hard-pressed to make such a formula work.I am very happy to report that I could not have been more wrong.  The plot is epic, in a quite literal sense; the rich and mysterious tapestry forming the backdrop for the action - the descriptions of the physical environments and the social, historical, and even mythological contexts in which the plot unfolds â€” is mesmerizing, horrifying, and heartbreaking all at once; and the central characters - Loken, Torgaddon, Karkasy [sp?], and Keeler in particular - are well-drawn and tremendously sympathetic.  If you enjoyed the Eisenhorn, Ravenor, and Gauntâ€™s Ghosts series, you will love this book.

bookDescription: The final part of book 8 of the global bestselling series, "The Horus Heresy: Siege of Terra".The Great Angel, Sanguinius, lies slain at his brotherâ€™s hand. Terra burns as reality itself unravels and the greatest bastion of civilisation teeters on the brink of annihilation. Desperate defenders gather, banding against the rabid traitor hordes. The Hollow Mountain, host to the pilgrims of Euphrati Keeler, is one of the last redoubts, held by the Dark Angels while the unclean host of Typhus lays siege. Malcador the Sigillite sits ablaze on the Golden Throne, trying to buy his master more time. But time is running outâ€¦ Guilliman races across the stars to reinforce the Throneworld. Will he return to ashes, where a Warmaster of Chaos has ascended to godhood, or will the Emperor have triumphed? And at what cost? It all comes down to one final, climactic confrontation: the Emperor versus Horus. The father against the son.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: While some might take issue with the lack of quantifiable feats and abilities from the Emperor and the general plot itself, I felt that the atmosphere was a fitting conclusion to an apocalyptic battle that has been built up towards over 17 years and dozens of moves and novellas. As a fan of 40k there will be things that frustrate you. The lore nerds in you will cry out. But at the end, it felt appropriate. The nightmare is over, and the dream will never be reclaimed, but it can be fought for. A new hell approaches inevitably, ten thousand years of terrible struggle and degradation as the faint concept of good becomes ever more elusive. But, in this day, here and now, the horror has subsided. An era has ended. Go into this with an open mind is what I advise, try and seek closure instead of hoping for something that will fit every preconception you have, and it will feel like what it should be.The end and the death.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: There's a longstanding critique of another SF author, Greg Egan, who writes science fiction with actual science in it (never happens in 40k), where his novels are basically little palimpsets to set his scientific stuff upon, and his characters are limp and flat.I think there's some of this going on in this book, where the sheer literal _number_ of the characters means that the Primarchs and like, Loken and stuff are the only ones that keep their integrity in this gigantic oceanic mass of the overarching strength of the setting. Characters are little figurines to hang the grand gothicness of the setting on. Literal hundreds of characters, they can't get equal screen time - obviously the fight between Horus and the Emperor is central stage, but lots of the rest is forgettable.Otherwise, it's a good book. I enjoy the Emperor remaining mysterious to the end, despite doing a lot of shonen anime stuff.

THE STORY
Terra is besieged. The outcome of the war lies on a knife edge. The Warmaster Horusâ€™ bloody seven-year crusade has led to this â€“ the cradle of humanity, where he is to kill his father, the Emperor.
With the war at this critical juncture, Sanguinius, primarch of the loyalist Blood Angels, braves the horrors of the Warmasterâ€™s flagship, The Vengeful Spirit, with a single purpose in mind â€“ to slay his brother Horus, decapitate the Heresy once and for all, and stop the forces of Chaos from taking Terra.
