productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Dan Abnett's work surprises, delights, terrifies, glorifies, horrifies, humbles, enlightens and confuses through metahphysical, allegorical and material/immaterial odyssey. The siege becomes a siege on the very concept of humanity, our very best and worst natures laid bare. A work that is the culmination of many hands and many ideas should feel consequential, and Siege doesn't disappoint and The End and the Death trilogy stands above it's worthy peers in the series. I wouldn't start reading unless you have a very free day, because you'll find the work enthralling and lose sense of time (perhaps a metaphysical spillover of un-time from the work in question?).

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Pares down the fluff from the 1st book and presses the peddle to the metal!
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Disregard that 1 star review from some whiner complaining and spoiling the novel for everyone else. It was written by someone who already decided beforehand that he hated this book. Just another 40k edgelord who can only complain about what *he* doesn't like and tries to ruin the game/lore/hobby for everyone else. We all know this type... he's a "that guy".Let's break it down, *without spoilers* as that's the appropriate approach. Obviously I'm going to take for granted that everyone knows that the Emperor is mortally wounded and the loyalists win a pyrrhic victory against Horus and Chaos. This battle is how the entire setting for the 40k universe is brought about. It's no secret. What these books (and all of the Horus Heresy novels) are doing is giving us incredible detail as to how exactly the 40k universe becomes what it is.Ok, that said, the first half of this book is *much* more about the supporting cast of characters than the 1st book. Malchador and the Emperor feature far less (though the Emperor does show up near the end for an epic, and sad, reveal) and with Malchador being almost entirely consumed by the Golden Throne his chapters are often nothing more than short, broken thoughts. More time is given to characters like Fo & Amon, John, Oll and the Companions, Rann, Azkaellon and the Astartes who were trapped outside after the Eternity Gate closed, Amit and the "Denial Companies" set up to defend the inner sanctum, Dorn who continues to try and figure out a way to get free from Khorne's trap, and finally Sanguinius in all his glory. Lastly, for brief chapters (all the chapters are extremely brief... maybe 10 pages at most, most are only 2 - 4 pages), the Emperor, Valdor and the few remaining Custodes. Valdor is perhaps the one with the least amount of "screen time", showing up for a couple chapters early on and then never brought up again. There's a decent amount of time given to the Emperor in the first quarter, then nothing for a long portion, only to show up near the end for some *really* important moments. Perhaps some of the most important moments in the entire storyline, outside of Sanguinius death and the final clash between Him and Horus.The first half can generally be split into 3 sections; outside the Palace, inside the Palace and the Vengeful Spirit. There's one aspect of this book that permeates every part and it's actually really wonderfully done, and that is the warp's complete breakdown of spacetime and geometry. The outside and inside of the palace quickly becomes meaningless... it's both and neither at the same time but I'm sticking toÂ the inside & outside designation toÂ justÂ make it easy. It started to happen during the 1st book but it *really* takes off in this one. *Nobody* is where they intend to be, not even the traitors. It can be subtle, like a winding staircase becoming counter-clockwise when it should have been clockwise, or entire structures (like a certain infamous prison) simply appearing dozens of kilometers away from where they should be. Characters frequently walk through one door only to appear impossibly far away from where they should be, sometimes not even on Terra any more. Even the inner sanctum is succumbing to the warp, making the nigh-unshakable Custodes feel unnerved (well, as close to unnerved as they can get).One thing is definitely certain though; the end of all things is imminent. Vulcan is even counseled to enact the "Seven Hammers" protocol, which will destroy the Golden Throne and all of Terra. The Dark King finally manifests itself, throwing everyone who looks upon it (on one side at least) into pure fright, yes even Astartes, and madness as they flee from it. Erebus shows up, chasing after John & his companions and really puts a hurt on the group. Abaddon veryÂ nearly kills him and I really wish he did. Erebus is just the absolute worst.Â Luckily for the loyalists, and once again thanks to the warp, time has stopped as well (which really pisses off the Dark Mechanicus as all of their machines start to fail). The first quarter of the book really dives in and drives home that nothing is proper and nothing can be trusted. Not senses, not direction, nothing. Orders are relayed on scribbled paper and run between units like a WW1 trench runner (but on jet bikes), dataslates and vox commo are long abandoned. *Nobody* is in communication with anyone from the Anabasis boarding party on the Vengeful Spirit *except* one could maybe make the argument for the 9th legion Astartes who constantly "dream" in their battle-weary fugue states of Sanguinius as he progresses through the ship in low orbit (obviously this tenuous, dream-like connection will be *VERY* important later on).Speaking of Sangunius, the 1st half deals with him and his personal guard fighting through the ranks of traitors to reach Horus. After that grueling battle, he is cut off from his guard and "lost" in darkness. Eventually *someone* shows up (not gonna say who) and helps guide Sanguinius out of the darkness and eventually to Horus. The final battle between Horus and Sanguinius is... well, it felt underwhelming to me. This is another instance where the outcome is no secret. Horus kills Sanguinius and while yes, it's sad, it's not as moving as I expected it to be. Maybe my own hype for this moment was built up too much (I mean, their battle is literally on the cover so I feel like *everyone* was hyped for this moment) but it didn't land like I expected it to. It's still wonderfully written and Abnett even made me think for a moment, "Wait, is Sanguinius going to win this fight?" even though it's already been well documented for many decades now that he doesn't. It was a joy to read Sanguinius actually start to piss Horus off and truly hurt him too, but we all know how it end and it ends... fast. Once Horus is able to actually catch him, he lands (basically) two blows and that's all he wrote. The first one cripples Sanguinius, the second kills him. I wanted it to be more emotional for me than it really was. Honestly, the reveal of the Dark King, the conversation (it) has with a certain character and the realization of what (it's) doing and what will happen because of (it's) decision, was more impactful for me than the fight between Horus and Sanguinius.The book suffers from the same issues the 1st one did, though not as bad, which is Abnett's *extreme* verbosity. I swear, I had to look up more words in the dictionary than I could count. Many are able to be interpreted from the way they're used in a sentence but combined with the totally made up words, about 100+ pages could be cut from the book just by exercising the fluff Abnett likes to throw in. It's not nearly as bad as the 1st book, which had literally back to back pages and pages of just made-up locations, characters and their titles who played no role beyond simply being names & titles. I won't say these books are his "best" work (I'm reserving judgement until all 3 are released and read), it's definitely his *grandest*. You can tell he put so much love and care into crafting these novels, which makes sense as these are the penultimate Horus Heresy storylines, and the fact that he wrote the first book some 2 decades ago that kicked this all off. Maybe a bit *too much* love and care, but if that's a fault...I'm also not sure how I feel about the liberal use of borrowed phrases from famous literary pieces with no reference to their origin. It feels... dishonest. "I will show you fear in a handful of dust" a line by T.S. Eliot for example, is used with zero reference to where it came from. Just tossed in as a lineÂ Khorne uses to taunt Dorn.Â This "borrowing" has been done throughout the Horus Heresy novels so you could give it a pass but I've never liked when they do this.Â Almost every novel (that I've read) contains lines like these. At other times, certain lines come across like when a movie character says the name of the movie. A character in the book says "the grim darkness of the far future" which is the well known tag line for 40k. A bit too tongue in cheek for the absolutely horrible events unfolding in this book and it just immediately makes me think of that Family Guy episode where they point and laugh at this trope. These moments are jarring and only serve to take me out of the story when I come across them.The good thing about this book is it's much more pared down than the 1st book. Gone are the truly massive amounts of filler. It's still a long book (650+ pages) but it reads VERY fast. With each chapter averaging 3 or 4 pages long, you really fly through it. Abnett has also cut down on the fluff words, creating a more direct and precise read, despite the mind-jarring twisting and dislocation every character experiences. If the 1st book sets up the premise and layout for every character, then this book is the streamlined version, stepping on the gas. Looking forward to the 3rd and final book to come out so we can really take them all in as one story. The end is truly really here, with the greatest story of the 40k universe only one book away from reaching its conclusion (Don't fret! There's still "The Scouring" plotlines to explore afterwards and A LOT happens during that. The Fallen, the 2nd Founding and the Codex Astartes, what happened to all of the remaining loyalistÂ Primachs, the traitor forces fleeing into the Eye of Terror/the Maelstrom... tales of revenge, violence and loss so epic asÂ they sweep out across the entire galaxy! It's when 40kÂ *really* becomes "modern" 40k).
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on November 23, 2023

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: The siege of Terra reaches fever pitch
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I had a great time reading this. I was waiting for it to be released with high anticipation. The stories inside these pages are woven masterfully. There is enough atmosphere and detail that you can imagine yourself right there, at the end of all things. A lot is revealed in this one, and there is a lot of sadness. The siege is almost over, the enemy has breached the walls and the defenders are fighting for their lives as enemies come from all sides. I'm trying to stay vague, as I don't want to spoil the book, but this one is a great read. Everything is coming to a head and everyone has lost control. No one is sure how or when it happened, but any semblance of military order is gone on both sides. Men brawl by firelight with hooks and clubs, but they can't remember even what they are fighting for anymore. A fifth great power of chaos is ready to be born, and its birth scream will be the end and the death of the human race.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Beautifully compelling story about "Imperial Truth" vs. the fanatical Imperial cult
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I LOVED how deeply this story delves into one of my favorite unresolved loose threads from the Horus Heresy... the tragedy of the Emperor's failure to spread reason through the galaxy through his so-called "Imperial Truth," when viewed against the infinitely superstitious and fanatical cult that now rules the galaxy in His name.Previously, I might have not called that particular thread unresolved... I would simply say that the Emperor lost, and the religious fanatics won, but now that Guilliman has been resurrected, reason and superstition are at war in the galaxy once again, and even the Primarch might be no match against the power of faith and fanaticism.And that's just one storyline (though, in my view, it's the most interesting and important one) in this novel. The main plot is ostensibly about Mortarian and his host of plague of demons continuing their assault on Ultramar, and the forces of the loyal primarch Guilliman doing battle against him, with reasonably exciting results. Other storylines include that of a newly assigned Novamarine of the Primaris type who is not fitting in with adopted culture of his new chapter and, my least favorite, a side plot concerning the battle between Imperial and Plague-tainted titans.But this book gets five stars for me since it is the most thoughtful, funny and tragic exploration of the Emperor's failure to spread reason and to vanquish superstition, since the Horus Heresy books. And Guilliman gains additional complexity here, after being too often portrayed as an idealistic Boy Scout.

bookDescription:
2018 Locus Award, Best Science Fiction Novel
Our universe is ruled by physics, and faster-than-light travel is not possible - until the discovery of The Flow, an extradimensional field we can access at certain points in space-time that transports us to other worlds, around other stars.
Humanity flows away from Earth, into space, and in time forgets our home world and creates a new empire, the Interdependency, whose ethos requires that no one human outpost can survive without the others. It's a hedge against interstellar war - and a system of control for the rulers of the empire.
The Flow is eternal - but it is not static. Just as a river changes course, The Flow changes as well, cutting off worlds from the rest of humanity. When it's discovered that The Flow is moving, possibly cutting off all human worlds from faster-than-light travel forever, three individuals - a scientist, a starship captain, and the empress of the Interdependency - are in a race against time to discover what, if anything, can be salvaged from an interstellar empire on the brink of collapse.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: One of my favorite sci fi books in years
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: "The humans malfunctioned long before their habitat did."The edges and boundaries of human experience and the possibilities beyond them are the things I like best in my science fiction. I found these in spades within The Collapsing Empire, along with humor alternately dry and caustic, characters I loved and loathed, and questions both alarming and intriguing.The Collapsing Empire is the first in a series called The Interdependency - the second, titled The Consuming Fire, is due out in October of 2018. It's a space opera set in a new universe, ostensibly hundreds of years into our future. Humanity has spread itself all over the galaxy, constrained by the exit points of the mysterious Flow through which spaceships can travel at speeds unheard-of in standard physics. Now, the Flow has begun to collapse - and we're told the Interdependency will soon follow.The story is told through the eyes of three characters - Kiva, Cardenia, and Marce. I found Marce a little forgetable, but that's primarily because Kiva - ruthless daughter of a merchant house - is so delightfully brash, and Cardenia, being the new Emperox of the Interdependency, is in much more interesting surroundings. Marce is hardly ignorable, though, as his father's research could be the key to anyone understanding the Flow's situation in time to act.As with all of Scalzi's novels, the writing is snappy and dialogue-heavy. When combined with the gripping story, this makes for a very fast read - so fast, in fact, that Scalzi had to write a blog post ensuring fans that it wasn't any shorter than average. It also makes for a fun audiobook, narrated by Wil Wheaton.As I mentioned, I especially loved Kiva. She has a strident love for vehement swearing, but that's far from her only avenue of profanity - she is also frankly and openly sexual, appraising current conversation partners as near future sex partners frequently and regardless of gender. The book treats same sex relationships and dalliances with a refreshingly casual attitude. Further, this is the first book I've read that considered same sex relationships as a viable option for political marriage! (Gideon's Riders does this too, but I read The Collapsing Empire first. I am now spoiled and will never accept a lack of full consideration again!)The science fiction I've liked best has always used a scientific conceit to ask a question about humanity. In The Collapsing Empire, the conceit is "what if faster-than-light travel wasn't even necessary?" The relevant technobabble is tongue-in-cheek, smoothing over the problem of faster-than-light travel by introducing the Flow, and then glossing over the Flow itself as too complex for proper explanation:"This was, of course, an absurd way of looking at the Flow. The Flow is not anything close to a riverâ€”it is a multidimensional brane-like metacosmological structure that intersects with local time-space in a topographically complex manner, influenced partially and chaotically but not primarily by gravity, in which the ships accessing it donâ€™t move in any traditional sense but merely take advantage of..."...and so on. Despite the brevity and intentional vagueness, the Flow is a novel way to surmount the issue, and serves its narrative function neatly.The question this book asks is what will happen when the politics of the few get in the way of the needs of the species...which is an all too topical question. Our own current political climate is in a maddeningly similar situation, and the comparison to the book is neither favorable nor hopeful, for me.Real-world analogs aside, the story is definitely its own entity, not a direct allegory for reality. Humanity has spread itself out along spindly connections, and then staked its chances of continued survival heavily on these connections. The Interdependency is built on heavily intertwined economic, religious, and governmental systems, each of which are interested primarily in ensuring their own survival, rather than the survival of the species. The three character perspectives through which we experience the events are a neat mirror for this triumvirate - each character is interested in preserving themselves and something beyond their own skin. (I won't go so far as to say the characters each represent one of the systems of power...yet. I might be convinced of this in future books.)This is one of my favorite science fiction books I've read in recent years, and I can't wait to read more.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2018

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: First was worth reading... not sure about the rest.
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I wanted to give this 5 stars... I just couldn't.  John is a very good author.  No doubt about that.  I like the book and the premise.  He weaves the tale together like a fine tapestry.  Political machinations, intrigue, some hard science fiction and a boatload of characters.  The most important statement and plot element may slip by most readers but he nails it and for that a tip of my hat.Definitely a fun read and it flew by because he doesnâ€™t overburden his writing with long drawn out descriptions of every little detail.  Letâ€™s face it, some authors spend 14 pages describing the weather around a scene.  A lot of us start flipping pages when it gets too deep.  John avoids that.I have a few issues with the book.  No spoilers here.  Most of this is mentioned in the marketing and look inside view on Amazon.Oneâ€¦ he made a mistake by claiming that â€œOur universe is ruled by physics. Faster than light travel is impossibleâ€¦â€  He then immediately creates a universe where those very laws are violated by his plot.  Sorry John, you took the science high ground on FTL and then proceeded to create something far more preposterous.  There is solid physics behind the concept of â€˜warpâ€™ drive as used in Star Trek.  FTL will be possibleâ€¦ well, if the human race survives itself that is.Twoâ€¦ although the names of ships are fun, they are a bit ridiculous.  I also think he should have skipped reading Dune before he wrote this.  He got lost in naming the characters with names that are hard to follow, pronounce and donâ€™t keep us clear on gender.  In a universe where earthlings are using all the language common for earthlings, he veers off and gives them names that make no cultural sense.  In Dune, the characters arenâ€™t from earth so their language and culture would flow different directions.  John mixes earth and non-earth terms with abandon.Threeâ€¦ the extreme overuse of the F word by people who are educated, successful and upper class.  Aside from the fact it was getting old, it was just unnecessary.  Iâ€™ve been in biker bars where I heard the F word less.  Even on the streets of New York City, where the F word is used as punctuation, it didn't wear on me as much as in this book.Again, liked the concept, like Johnâ€™s writing style.  Just think he bounced off of some things that should have been left in the editorâ€™s trash can.  Honestly, Iâ€™m not sure Iâ€™ll read the rest of the series.  Iâ€™ve already read Dune more than once.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: Saboroso, cheio de emoÃ§Ãµes, atentados, mortes, reviravoltas ...Faz lembrar a sÃ©rie FundaÃ§Ã£o de Isaac Asimov, pois trata-se da previsÃ£o do fim de um impÃ©rio atual (a interdependÃªncia).Ao final fica o suspense de uma continuaÃ§Ã£o :-)

This is a new, rich universe. If you enjoyed the Old Man's War books, you will find a million things to love. And if you're new to Scalzi, you will simply be astounded by his fresh and breezy style and dialogue. Scalzi writes real grownups, people who have interesting motivations and appetites, and his universes are unapologetically diverse. Along with hilarious and sexy, in equal measure! I caught myself laughing out loud frequently, as characters made wry internal observations that were absolutely delightful. Scalzi's writing is fresh and his plotting is tight. Highly recommend.
This book, in the same way as his other space novels, is a surprising mixture of light reading and yet well developed characters and plot.A definite recommendation for Sci fi fans.

Humour and science fiction do not often align to create a memorable read. John Scalzi has managed to marry both to create a future universe that is both well-fleshed out and enjoyable to engage with. I look forward to catching up on the interdependency in the future.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.username: Married to she who must be obeyed
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: After reading so many of Scalzi books in the last few week this is the one that really puts him 'up there' with the sci fi greats of Asimov , Arthur Clarke, & Frank Herbert.a whole new concept of realism in sci fi, what if space travel took ages between planets?, theres no warp drive, faster than light drive.  What if the only way to even travel between far distance planets was to piggy back into a space flow which were "one way streets" and you needed a flow in either direction to 'go and come back'? Then what if these flows have existed for thousands of years and you base your whole empire and the future of humanity and your economy on this space travel and then find that these flows might not be as stable as you think? Thats the under laying concept of this book about battling companies wanting to feed their profits and wanting to control the whole of humanity. I have become a fan of Scalzi since Covid 19 created Lockdown and I have read a lot of his books in the last four months, I'm married to author Jean Fullerton and I know how hard she works on plots, research, characterisation and 'story lines', basically she says its an 8 hour a day job, so I get to see her when she 'clocks off'. Mr Scalzi judging from your output and the quality of your books and plots I dont think you can ever leave your desk: you must live the life of a hermit because your head must be so full of stories; you have written such a variety of works so your family can't ever see you because you must always be writing the next one. But thankyou to your family and to you because I have really enjoyed every thing youve written, and i still have many more to read. Its hard to find a new author who can deliver 'the goods' Scalzi is my go to guy for a damn good read;  I recommend this author to all sci fi fans.

The final enemy has been revealed, and it's more insidious than Van could ever imagine, spanning space and time with the patience of immortalityâ€”and an utter disregard for all forms of life.
On the run and broken, the Equal Grasp faces elimination on earth and everywhere else, their leader gone, their mission a shambles, and with new agents of justice hard on their heels.
But the fight isn't over. In fact, it's just begun, and Van knows that every decision he's made for the past decade will come to bear on who lives, and who diesâ€”and who is meant to rule over a universe where freedom and justice are the ultimate pursuit.
At any cost, Van and his crew will finish the job, but they're going to need a lot of help from people and beings who have been observers.
Until now.
The time for watching is over. The time for victory is now. But the cost might be more than anyone can pay, and Van is no longer merely an agent of justice. He's a father, a husband, and a friendâ€”and he's going to need every connection in the stars to defeat the ultimate enemy and save his people.

bookDescription: Long after Earth's destruction, Humanity is an endangered species...When freighter pilot Dalton Thorne reunites with his old friend Kota at Little Earth's best noodle shop, he's expecting a straightforward job. Instead, he finds himself embroiled in a centuries-old mystery that could change humanity's place in the universe forever.Little Earth is a decaying city carved into an alien planet where humans live as refugees.Beneath its neon-lit streets and crowded markets lies a secret: fragments of Earth's past, preserved by a mysterious race of aliens and hidden from the ruling Consortium.Now, Dalton and his fledgling crew must uncover a vital piece of evidence, long buried in depths of Little Earthâ€”one that might lead to a real home for humanity.With combat-enhanced martial artists, power-hungry crime lords, and the iron fist of the Consortium all hot on their trail, Dalton must navigate a web of divided loyalties and hard choices.If only he'd kept eating his noodles, none of this would have happened.Grab your copy of "Big Trouble, Little Earth" today and join Dalton Thorne on a journey that will take him from the depths of Little Earth to the secrets of humanity's forgotten past.

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: Dalton's noodles are spoilt by a bad day. It was meant to be a simple delivery but turned into a day of chases, near death experiences and a inter-dimensional struggle for the universe itself. Fast paced action with an element of historical mystery. Dalton and his band really need to stop raising flags and challenging the universe by saying silly things like, what could go wrong? and it couldn't get any worse could it? Each time the universe answers this insolent challenge with prejudice. I enjoyed it and will be picking up the sequel.
A rollicking yarn, easy to read but a bit to removed from my hard SF preferences to be truly enjoyable.

bookDescription:
Retired from his fighting days, John Perry is now village ombudsman for a human colony on distant Huckleberry. With his wife, former Special Forces warrior Jane Sagan, he farms several acres, adjudicates local disputes, and enjoys watching his adopted daughter grow up.
That is, until his and Jane's past reaches out to bring them back into the game â€” as leaders of a new human colony, to be peopled by settlers from all the major human worlds, for a deep political purpose that will put Perry and Sagan back in the thick of interstellar politics, betrayal, and war.
The highly anticipated conclusion to John Scalzi's SF trilogy begun with Old Man's War and The Ghost Brigades concludes with The Last Colony

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I'm writing the same review for all of the John Scalzi books that I've read. If you want to know what this book's about, read the description and the sample. I'd only be repeating that info here. What I want you to know is that Scalzi is a genius Writer (with a capital "W"). "Writer" seems so pedestrian when referring to Scalzi. Better to describe him as "Novelist" or "Storyteller" or "Wordmonger" (maybe not that last one). Or "Craftsman." His stories are clever and brilliant, all unique, humorous and dramatic, believable...yet out there. If you want to get your mind off your troubles, or the troubles of the world, or you want to let go of your disbeliefs willingly (like a movie), or you need some frivolity, or you like plot twists and turns, or you think you can guess what's coming next or later in a story (like I do) but you get it totally wrong, or you just want a tale that blows your mind, read one of John Scalzi's books. I guarantee that you will be totally ecstatic, if not downright jubilant. You're welcome.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on November 12, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: The Last Colony is the third book in the series. If you haven't read the other two, Old Man's War and The Ghost Brigades, then I urge you to get your hands on them and read them. The Ghost Brigades was probably my favorite of the series, but really, all of the books, including the novelette, The Sagan Diaries, are good and contribute to the overall story arc.As of this moment, I think this may be the weakest book of the three, but don't take that as a criticism. I often find it takes me a little while after reading a story to fully appreciate it. By writing this review right away I'm being unfair. I haven't had time to appreciate the subtleties.I'm amazed by how well Scalzi was able to surprise me with the story. Yet, he somehow, comfortingly, allowed me to predict a few things. I like that combination.The story progressed at a good pace, constantly keeping me entertained, unlike Excession, where I felt bogged down for days and weeks suffering through what seemed like mindless background to get to the good stuff. In the end Excession paid off, but I didn't have to wait until the ending twist for The Last Colony to pay off.*** Spoilers Below ***Even though I feel all glowy about the book, I do have a few complaints. I didn't feel much for the new characters. When Hiram Yoder is killed it should be a poignant scene, but it isn't. Yes, I feel a loss of someone important to the colony, but not to the story. Even Savitri, who is an interesting character to be sure, lacks the depth that gives me any feeling for her. Hickory and Dickory are the only new characters that I really felt a sense of attachment.I felt much more for the characters introduced in the other two novels: John, Jane, Jared, Harry, even Szilard and Boutin.I'm also a little disappointed that the werewolves disappeared after a critical scene. What happened between them and the colony? Was it possible to negotiate? I know it would have needlessly extended the book to go into those details, but I still wonder.Overall though, it's an excellent end to the series. Scalzi wrapped up the plot and the series in a happy ending without making it sappy or unbelievable. In the afterward he said he wouldn't be coming back to these characters. Although I'll miss them, I'm glad. As I get older my patience for long series grows short. Even though each book he's written so far can stand alone, I don't think I could stand another 10 year series.He hasn't left out the possibility of returning to the world again one day and I look forward to new stories from this world.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2007

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: In "The Last Colony," the third installment of John Scalzi's captivating Old Man's War series, readers are treated to a thrilling and thought-provoking journey across the galaxy. Scalzi's mastery of storytelling shines through in this gripping tale of conflict, politics, and the human spirit.At the heart of the novel is protagonist John Perry, a retired soldier who finds himself thrust back into the midst of interstellar intrigue. Perry's wit, resilience, and moral compass make him a compelling and relatable hero, as he navigates the challenges of leadership and the complexities of interstellar diplomacy.Scalzi's world-building is nothing short of extraordinary, as he crafts a richly detailed universe filled with alien species, advanced technology, and political intrigue. From the bustling colonies of humanity to the enigmatic enclaves of alien civilizations, the novel is populated with vividly realized characters and settings that leap off the page.The pacing of the novel is relentless, as Scalzi keeps readers on the edge of their seats with a series of twists and turns that keep the plot moving at breakneck speed. From pulse-pounding action sequences to tense political negotiations, "The Last Colony" is a rollercoaster ride of excitement and suspense that will leave readers eager for more.But what truly sets "The Last Colony" apart is its exploration of themes such as identity, loyalty, and the nature of conflict. Scalzi deftly weaves these deeper philosophical questions into the fabric of the narrative, challenging readers to confront their own beliefs about morality and the human condition.In addition to its thrilling plot and thought-provoking themes, "The Last Colony" is buoyed by Scalzi's trademark wit and humor. The novel is filled with laugh-out-loud moments and witty banter between characters, adding a layer of levity to the often-dark subject matter.Overall, "The Last Colony" is a stellar addition to John Scalzi's Old Man's War series, delivering all the action, intrigue, and heart that fans have come to expect from the acclaimed author. With its compelling characters, richly imagined world, and thought-provoking themes, "The Last Colony" is a must-read for science fiction enthusiasts of all stripes. It earns a well-deserved five stars and solidifies Scalzi's place as one of the genre's preeminent storytellers.

The Last Colony is the third book in a (currently) six book series with a few novella's thrown in. If you haven't heard of them before, please start with Old Man's War, the first in the series as it's an ongoing story line and you won't understand a lot of what is going on without them.So with that disclaimer pout of the way!  I really enjoyed the first two books in the series and the third book, was equally engrossing. I sped through it in two days. If you liked the first two novels, you'll like this is the short version.To the slightly longer version! The Last colony focuses on The Old Man's War protagonist John Perry again. Thanks to the results of The Ghost Brigade he has managed to leave the military and settle down with his new wife Jane Sagan and their adopted daughter Zoe. Everything is peaceful despite the universe's conflicts but unfortunately that won't last as John, Jane and Zoe are hand picked to lead a new colony. It's a special circumstance and they need them as neutral leaders yet with military and administrative skills to deal with what's ahead. However the Colonial Defense Force aren't telling them everything and the situation is far worse then they realize....The thing I really like about the series so far is each book has been pretty different yet still obviously set in the same universe. It starts off a little slower than the previous books but I greatly enjoyed the more political and survivalist set up it builds and I think it ties up a lot of events pretty nicely overall. The characters are all still really great (I especially like Jane) and some interesting new ones are introduced. The writing style continues to be easy to read with great pacing so I never felt bored or confused about what was going on.Overall, another great book in the series. Recommended.+ Interesting story setting.+ Great characters.+ Easy to read with great pacing.

aPlusContent.title: From the Publisher
aPlusContent.rawText:
From the Publisher
Impossible odds meet impossible choices in a thrilling space adventure 
Solarhaven Alliance Marine veteran Jace Hawthorne only wants to protect his family while surviving under the oppressive rule of alien overlords. He's heard rumors of fiery rebellions and buried alien technologies, fleeting hopes that allies are waiting to overthrow their cruel leaders. But to Jace, those rumors are nothing but unsubstantiated gossip. 
Until a routine smuggling job turns catastrophic and lands him in a world of shadows and intrigue. He faces a monumental decision that could save humanity--or doom it. Jace quickly learns the most important choices aren't the ones you make but the ones that make you.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This is the first book of a space-based Science Fiction series. As such, it gives some background and current-day events before getting into the 'meat' of the story.The story starts out focusing on Jace. He's a military combat veteran of the opposition forces to the current government. This led to him spending time in a government prison. Upon his release, his only viable option for employment is to work for a shadowy organization. The only reason he remains on his home planet and works for them is to assist his ailing mother and his retired combat veteran father. As the story unfolds, Jace is forced into making hard decisions that affect his future.As a reader, I love that the book had a touch of mystery and intrigue. I'm looking forward to reading the next books in the series.Disclaimer: I was invited, along with other readers, to read this book. I voluntarily agreed to do so. Above are my honest thoughts on this book.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: very hard to read because almost every sentence is treated as a paragraph.  no clue why anyone would write this way. learn how to write in English please. Update: thought I should clarify. Almost every sentence is separated by a blank line. In a few cases, a few sentences may form a paragraph, but most commonly every sentence is separated like a paragraph. Reading this is a bit like trying to read while traveling down a road full of potholes, you keep getting jarred and have to take a second to get back to where you were. A well written book should flow, word to word, sentence to sentence, and paragraph to paragraph leading the reading smoothly through the story. This book is the direct opposite of that.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I really enjoyed this series.  The plot, the universe building, the character development and the storytelling have all been solid.  The ending, though, I just thought it was rushed a bit, with too many loose ends needing tied up in a hurry and an impossible outcome handwaved into existence.  I wish a little more effort would have gone into solving the problem in a realistic (for this series) way rather than blah blah blah oh crap we're all doomed wait nevermind Skippy just came up with some magic that's not going to be explained type situation. It seemed a bit lazy.  Overall, however, I loved the story and I'm glad I stuck with it, even if the ending needed a polish.  Thanks for keeping me mostly engaged and entertained the past half decade Craig.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Best conclusion to a series I can recall reading
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: If you are a fan of Joe and Skippy and the whole crowd of characters then I think you will like this book very much. It checks all the boxes, but never feels like it is checking boxes. It feels like a good tale, well told, that grew naturally. Plenty of humor, and the dialog is almost always just right. There is plenty of the usual bantering and sometimes bickering. I am trying to avoid spoilers, so no specifics. The Merry Band have their work cut out for them, and as usual they will have to "punch above their weight" as Simms puts it. Way above. Because, Elders coming and you should be terrified. So, it is kind of a swan song. Or not. Depending on how you read between the lines and whether you correctly guess which way the twists will go.I am in my sixties and have read literally thousands and thousands of SF books and almost as many short stories. This concluding novel is probably the best final installment I have ever read in SF and among the best of any kind of fiction I have read. Will most readers find some things make them unhappy? Of course. There is no such thing as perfection. Well, except for Skippy the Magnificent, duh. (Also, it is not much of a spoiler to reveal that everyone's favorite sketchy con artist Jeraptha, Captain Scorandum of the ECO is in the book. Along with everyone's favorite Jeraptha aide to Scorandum, Kinsta. Good times.)Yes, it is a long book, but it flies by. A page turner. Enjoy. I will not say, "Trust the awesomeness". Nobody's luck lasts forever, right? ðŸ˜ŽðŸ˜ŽðŸ˜ŽðŸ˜ŽðŸ˜Ž

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This series is the most fun you could have in sci-fi.  Skippy and Joe, the best buddy comedy in this spacetime.  Anything you can laugh about, you can overcome should be the moral of the story.  Also cheeseburgers and fluffernutters go a long way to overcoming the dangers of low morale in space.  Good bye you magnificent goofballs.  And goodbye Smythe.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2023

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I have loved this series since book 1.  I have read every book and have enjoyed the series.  They got repetitive at times and I feel like some parts could have moved faster than others but overall I felt it ended the series well enough.I do wish there had been a bit more to the end because I felt there was enough still there to at least continue the story even if it was with a different set of characters.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Enjoyed the book, sad to see certain characters are no longer part of the series but that is life in the Milky Way.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: The first thing I didn't like was getting started on book 8 and having missing pieces of the story and having to search out this junk.That said, this was really crap.  They got some relatively big names for it - but it well and truly sucked.  I don't know if this was actually a money grab as others have stated but it certainly wasn't worth the 20 bucks I paid.The audio quality was inconsistent, the story telling was poor, I ended up fast-forwarding through the last hour and a half of the thing to make sure I didn't miss any big points, but I just wanted it to be over.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 15, 2020

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: A good addition to the Series.
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: A nice addition to the lore of Joe and the Magnificent Skippy. Although I did enjoy the live action drama and story, it wasnt quite what I expected. I found the production to be a little corny in some places. RC Bray of course brings it home with his wonderful voice acting, also Kate Mulgrew was a treat to listen to and nailed her performace as the Nagatha A.I. I am a fan of Quinto and he has a great body of work, I just wasnt feeling it with his performance in this production. It was like his heart wasnt in it, and it came off a bit wooden. The story was a bit over the top and overemphasized military sterotypes a wee too much.Despite my minor gripes, I was entertained and enjoyed listening to, though not always ageering with, the intreptations the actors brought to each character. I would recommend it to any fan of Alanson's work and continuation of his series.

author: John French
breadCrumbs: Books > Science Fiction & Fantasy > Science Fiction > Adventure

attributes.value: Siege of Terra: The Horus Heresy

#2,818 in Audible Books & Originals (See Top 100 in Audible Books & Originals)#41 in Military Science Fiction (Audible Books & Originals)#74 in Military Science Fiction (Books)#80 in Space Opera Science Fiction (Audible Books & Originals)

bestsellerRanks.category: Space Opera Science Fiction (Audible Books & Originals)

bookDescription:
The Siege of Terra Book 1
After years of devastating war, Horus and his forces have arrived at Terra. But before they can set foot on the Throneworld, they must first break the defences of the Sol System.
Powerful fleets and cunning defences bar their path - but can anything hope to halt the advance of the Traitor armada?
Listen to it because:
The final act of the long-running, best-selling series starts here, with a brutal and uncompromising look at the first stage of the Siege of Terra, the war to conquer the solar system. Armies will fall, heroes will rise and legends will be written....
The Story
After seven years of bitter war, the end has come at last for the conflict known infamously as the Horus Heresy. Terra now lies within the Warmasterâ€™s sights, the Throneworld and the seat of his fatherâ€™s rule. Horusâ€™ desire is nothing less than the death of the Emperor of Mankind and the utter subjugation of the Imperium. He has become the ascendant vessel of Chaos and amassed a terrible army with which to enact his will and vengeance.
But the way to the Throne will be hard as the primarch Rogal Dorn, the Praetorian and protector of Terra, marshals the defences. First and foremost, Horus must challenge the might of the Sol System itself and the many fleets and bulwarks arrayed there.
To gain even a foothold on Terran soil, he must first contend the Solar War. Thus the first stage of the greatest conflict in the history of all mankind begins.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: A Desperate Plan... To wring just a bit more money out of this...
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: "Almost a decade and a half, and over 5,000,000 words have passed since the moment Horus spoke on the page for the first time in Horus Rising"-John French2,000,000 words too many at the very least.After Legion, Black Library quickly realized that the HH story was progressing WAY too quickly so they started feeding us new material in drips and drabs...How many versions of the Drop Site Massacre did we have to hear about?This is why I believe almost all books since [Legion] have been of poorer quality (notable exceptions: A Thousand Sons, Prospero Burns, and Know No Fear). What started as a terrific backstory and foundation to the 40k universe became a cash cow... We deserved better...That being said, Horus Rising was my first WH40k book and it opened a door to a virtual flood of bolter-porn and grimdark... I've loved almost all of it (Damnation of Pythos, Vulkan Lives... I can't get that time back) and John French delivers.This is a great setup for what (is hopefully) a concise conclusion to the Horus Heresy saga. Seriously, if they string this out for more than five books I'm gonna have to plan a trip to Nottingham!French appears to really care about the content and the stories that have been (and have yet to be) told... Buy his book, reward good storytelling...But get your act together Black Library! I only have a few thousand (more) dollars to spend on your books!!!
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2019

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I haven't read a lot of Horus Heresy books but I've read enough and know enough of 40k/30k lore to know the personas involved. I also play a lot of 40k video-games and this book was basically battlefleet gothic(one of my all time fave games) come to life in book form. Great story line and great macro cannon porn, probably the best fleet battle book in the 40k setting. But definitely not a book for someone just starting out in the lore. This and the last Horus Heresy book I read, the master of mankind were really good and well worth the purchase.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: As always, epic in proportions, thoughtful in its depth.
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: If one had neglected to read this masterful series from the beginning, one might expect this science fiction/fantasy book to be in the same cadre of most books in its genre. However, John French, much like his contemporary black library authors, adds a depth of philosophy and introspection that is pleasantly.... surprising? For me, perhaps not. I have grown accustomed to it by now.If you, as a reader, are considering picking up this or the next book without having read the preceding 50-something books leading up to this point... STOP. Go back to the beginning. Pick up Horus Rising and prepare for a long, captivating journey through imagination and reflection. Its well worth the journey. Enjoy....
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on December 24, 2021

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: We get the start of the Siege, and there is a lot of call backs.There a number of main characters, but to me, the star is Mersadie Oliton, and I'm so glad she is back and gets the role she deserves.  The writing around her is great, as well as her story arc.Also, my favorite Ahriman is back, and boy does he think what hes' doing is a bad idea......The combat is great, as Horus grinds down the Outer Defenses.  Pluto, my goodness.If I hadn't read Sigismund's fate, I'd think he was doomed here for sure.Also comes with 4 B&W illustrations.  Admiral Su-Kassen is my favorite, though my wife picks Ahirman.Definite must get.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Fun Space Marine content, but little progress.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: In a galaxy where there is no black and white - really only the blackness of one or many egos in constant battle this book pulls no punches and lays it all bare. productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This work is the third book in the growing series telling the tale of the Horus Heresy, a pivotal historical event in Games Workshop's Warhammer 40K fictional universe. Most of the characters from the first two novels carry through to this one: Garviel Lorken and Tarik Torgaddon of the Sons of Horus, Saul Tarvitz of the Emperor's Children, Nathanial Garro of the Death Guard, and Kyril Sindermann the remembrancer. In addition, we get appearances by a number of primarchs and other dramatis personae recognizable from the tabletop game.I have been critical of Ben Counter's work in the past, which has been short on plot even though he typically writes good action scenes. However, in this work he surpasses his earlier efforts, providing excellent character interaction worthy of Abnett along with solid action sequences throughout. Instead of writing bad, difficult to believe "seduction by the Warp" scenes, which tripped up Graham McNeill in the second book, he presents much of it after the fact as loyalist characters question how it all could have gone so wrong so fast - and does it well.The plot focuses on the few individuals who resist the growing tide of corruption with the Crusade, and does a credible job continuing the outstanding development started by Dan Abnett in Horus Rising. Counter follows them through the battles and conflicts that he writes so well, but still does a surprisingly solid job at depicting the creep of injustice and tyranny through Horus' forces.The weakest portion of the book is the ending, which ham-handedly forces things into position for the next author in the series (Flight of the Eisenstein by James Swallow), as well as inducing a cliffhanger of sorts.In short: generally well written and entertaining throughout, it's well worth a read for any fan of 40K novels. As an added bonus, it took away the bad taste left in my mouth after finishing False Gods.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on February 5, 2007

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Phantom Deadfall Book 3 of Ruins of the Earth Series
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: 'Ruins of the Earth Book 3'  proves that things can ... nah, I'm not telling. So, here we are at Book 3, Phantom Deadfall, the latest series from the excellent minds of writers Christopher Hopper and J.N. Chaney. The battle continues, and the stakes are even higher because now we are fighting them on home turf. The team is together and ready to kick some aliens' a... it will be a difficult task, especially since the invaders are really PO'd!I hope you've read the first two books. Otherwise, it'll be like taking a bath with your clothes on. You'll hate it and feel really stupid. Catch up, 'cause there's a lot happening in Phantom Deadfall. Once again, R.C. Bray brings his unique storytelling talent that brings each character to life. -Mr.Bill

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Chapter 15 paragraph 1 states that Van is one-quarter Hu'warde because his Grandmother, Valint is Hu'warde. Van is a minimum of one-half Hu'warde because his Mother Jocelyn is also Hu'warde. This appears to be a grievous error made by Author Maggert. Its highly doubtful that J. N. Chaney would've made an error of this magnitude. I have read too many books in series by that Author Chaney that had no issues with continuity.  So I will lay the blame at the feet of the Secondary Author Terry Maggert, the beta readers, and the Editor. Let's not forget the AI that somehow missed the Family Tree legend in the Preview area in the front of this book.  Disappointing to read that knowing so many did not take the opportunity to update that paragraph. To await months for this book to finally arrive, makes this error absolutely difficult to digest.

bookDescription:

All over the Alliance, planets and colonies are suddenly under attack by the vicious Coven Empire.Freedom and her sister ship, Hood, are ambushed by alien warships, leaving Hood drifting dead in the void.Cole is ordered to salvage parts from the powerless Hood, but when he arrives on the unpowered hulk, Freedom is called away, marooning him and a group of malcontent techs in deep space.With the timer on survival ticking down, Cole must find the confidence to take control, whip his tiny crew into shape, bring Hood back to lifeâ€“â€“repairing communications, propulsion and even weapons.He's got one chance to transform the derelict ship into a combat-ready vessel. productPageReviews.reviewTitle: I'm givin' her all she's got, Captain!!
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This book had just about everything... Warp speed! Impulse engines! Exploding consoles! and a complete absence of seatbelts! Apparently the technology for seat restraints was lost in some earlier era.Aside from that, for its length, this book did a great job of creating characters, building a story, and keeping your attention! It's a great tale of a bunch of greenies showing courage under fire, and a captain doing everything in his power to save lives! It's also a story of a bunch of young engineers rallying behind their captain and giving it all to get the job done!It's not hard sci-fi, and it's not Hamlet. But it does what it is meant to do; entertain. So if you like books that harken back to the golden years of sci-fi, with bodies flying from explosions, enemy vessels that dwarf anything the good guys have, and people facing odds that would make you crawl in an escape pod, hit the eject and self-destruct buttons at the same time, you'll like this book!

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: An excellent read, albeit flawed by hard science
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: This is an extremely well written novel, entertaining and enthralling.  It kept me engaged from the first page to the last - in fact, I enjoyed it so much that having first borrowed it on Kindle Unlimited, I then bought a copy, to give the author the benefit of double earning.  I'm looking forward to the next two books in the series.That said, the book's major flaw - and it's a big one - is that it ignores the limitations of hard science in so blatant a way as to make it difficult to suspend disbelief.  I'm not talking about standard tropes like faster-than-light travel, or that sort of thing:  almost every SF author uses them, and we're used to them.  What grates is when a spaceship can brake from speeds greater than light to a standstill in the time it takes to read this sentence, or when a spaceship is used to ram another spaceship at faster-than-light speeds.  You and I know that even the barest touch of ship upon ship at such speeds would produce one of the most stupendous explosions in the galaxy, and utterly destroy both craft;  yet, in this book, it becomes a tactic that the hero uses more than once.  At low speeds (I'm talking tens, rather than hundreds or thousands of miles per hour) ramming becomes feasible.  Any faster, and it's a non-starter (except as a rather flashy way to commit suicide).  For such flaws, I had to deduct one star from what would otherwise have been a five-star review.However, the book is still very entertaining, and I liked it enough that I've pre-ordered the next two volumes in the series.  I just wish the author would be a bit more careful in crossing the scientifically believable line!

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: This is a very long book... and could easily have been split into two of them. So I started it with some trepidation, not knowing how far I would get through before I gave up.Instead, I found that it was hard to put it down and I devoured it at every opportunity, finishing it over a long weekend. The action was remorseless yet gripping and with different scenarios each major event. I dare say that much didn't conform to our current understanding of physics, but it was handled in such a way that it didn't seem to matter.The central character was unexpectedly thrust into his role but rose to the occasion and became a genuine hero, a natural leader... all whilst coming across as a thoroughly pleasant character, doubts and fears not withstanding.I don't often give 5 stars but I didn't feel I could do otherwise in this case... and I am seriously considering buying the remaining 2 books in the series, although book 2 is based on a planet.

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Been a fan of the series since the beginning, and I looked forward to this latest addition. However, as I finished the book, I felt as though this story had been pieced together and it lacked cohesion. It just felt like multiple vignettes taped together to make another book.For example, I usually reread the previous book in the series so I can flow right into the new. Yet this work seemed to completely ignore what had happened between and Galina and MacGill at the end of Throne World. Their initial interactions in Rebel World seem contrary to what was just established. That is one example of many, and it made this book feel a lot more Luke a stand-alone project.Also, I am nor sure why there were little observations made by MacBook throughout this story. I don't recall this being part of his style to this point so it seemed out of character for him to notice things like little dents in someone's armor or a smudge on someone's uniform. I thought the author was developing something about the main character that would be used later in the work, but he did not. Once again, it seemed to make the read a bit disjointed.I will commend Larson for turning it around at the end by sliding back into the approach and narrative that, in my opinion, has worked so far. It actually has me interested in what happens next.An ok read that propagated the storyline ahead some, but not the most compelling narrative in the series. Hopefully the next book will return to form.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on November 27, 2024

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: After religiously keeping up with the exploits of the Undying Mercenaries through all 22 novels, I found the first third of this story distracting to the point that it was nearly unreadable. The word 'like' is used over 900 times in the novel as a simile to compare a simple description to a contrived, hillbilly analogy. As a person who grew up. in the Deep South, I found them overly embellished and hyperbolized. We donâ€™t talk like that.For the first third of the story I wondered if the protagonist, McGill, was written by the original author. Normally conceived as an intelligent conman with questionable character, the new McGill in the first half of the book was simply a conniving fool. Elements of the story surrounding him, such as the tortured-and-revived sequence, appeared edited in from a previous story, and his interaction with other recurring characters seemed inconsistent with previous novels.But then, roughly halfway through the story, the use of similes in every description suddenly stopped, the novel smoothed out, McGill's typical character was restored. I wonder if there were an effort to use AI, if a young ghost writer wrote some of the novel, or if B.V. Larson were just having fun with the English language by stuffing in a simile behind every adjective.One loose end that I tracked was the recurring mention of the tiny scratches and marks that McGill noticed throughout the book. I kept waiting for a tiny alien, or a robotic entity, or one with a hard shell carapace to make an appearance. It dangled. Perhaps more will surface in subsequent books, just as I am awaiting more of the buried bunker hidden by earthâ€™s patriots in the past of the storyline. So far the mere mention of that pre-war period has been verboten to the characters. Maybe that is reserved as an opportunity for a spin-off series.Good story, numerous open elements for future development, a little distracting to read.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2024

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: I've read everyone is this collection, and I can't wait for the next one. McGill is awesome if you haven't read it yet then it's a must read

McGill is still up to his old tricks. He finds himself a star witness in several high level galactic court cases and is his usual bull in a china shop self. The grand admiral is not a character I have ever felt sympathy for but he came close in this one. No one alien or other deserves to be on the receiving end of the insidious McGill creature and his ways. Especially when he tells the truth! Earth's grip on the province of 921 is threatened by the proxy battle between the powers of the galactics and once again the legions march and die over and over. Something that kept cropping up was McGill noticing scratches, dents and minor imperfections in the people and environment around him. Is it a writing tick missed in the editing process or is it foreshadowing for events in future entries? The leadership of the legions in this series has always been completely dysfunctional and this reaches new levels in this one. Given human history and the revival tech possible in this universe it is only too believable. A long serving character also gets a long deserved promotion. I would like him to do well as compatant leadership would be a nice change for the legion.
I have always known these series to be an entertaining. BV Larson and his character McGill are remarkable.Eagerly await the next in line; especially after the ending of Rebel World.
Really great, entertaining and funny military sci-fu series. Hopping that James get promoted in the next instalment to Primus ðŸ˜

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: There's nothing "backyard" about The Backyard Starship series
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I'm a five decade scifi novel enthusiast. From Isaac Asimov to Roger Zelazny, it's been my favorite genre since I started reading in grade school, where I found Madeleine L'Engle "A Wrinkle in Time".Today, J. N. Chaney & his co-authors of a variety of scifi series, take up a lot of my reading time.It couldn't be better spent. But for my money, The Backyard Starship is the best of Chaney's work. Even after 22 novels, there is nothing stale about the characters or the story arc.If you only read 1 science fiction series this year, choose The Backyard Starship. I plan to re-read the entire series this coming winter.Get to know Van, Torina, Perry, Netty, Netty-P, Icky, Rob, Gabby, Funboy and The Fafnir, start with book #1 and sooner than you think , you'll have read them all!

The story
The walls have fallen. The defenders are broken. The Inner Palace lies in ruins.

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Long story but a solid ending
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Book seven of the Siege of Terra and Aaron Dembski-Bowden delivers a sold footing for the final two books to finish on.  It is a sad and disheartening story for the most part with the Loyalists on their back foot for most of it. The breaching of the final defenses of the Imperial Palace and the final closing of the Eternity Gate.  Then in all the loss there is the melding of the loyalist forces into a stoic and lethal force.  Sanguinius' defeat of his demonic brother and Ka'banda are the best part.  Read it by all means.  If I had a real criticism for the book it is a bit long in some places.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on July 27, 2023

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: The author of this book, Aaron Dembski-Bowden has a track record of taking Warhammer lore to its full potential.  This is without a doubt his best novel, and has narrowly taken its place as my favorite Warhammer novel (of any of the settings), of all time.  The reality of a six month siege, with the absurd technological/metaphysical capabilities of other armies is pushed to maximum realism here.To be blunt, this book can be brutal.  There are scenes that are grotesque and tough to read but they always have a point.  Nonetheless, I ended this book feeling something.  Drained, hopeful, and haunted all at the same time.  This book is incredible.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on September 22, 2022

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: The Siege Comes to an End..Almost
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: I will be the first to admit that sometimes, ADB's writing has not been as great for me as seems to be the consensus. The grimmerdark gets a bit old, and I wish occasionally the bad guys would suffer a bit more for being bad.But. Then he writes something like this....AND TOTALLY REDEEMS HIMSELF. This novel feels like a living thing. It is heavy, I read it a chapter at a time because they were so brutal and real. If you ever thought that the followers of Chaos got off clear and free- well my friend you won't for long.The Blood Angels finally shine, if in a tragic and dark way. I want more from ADB on the Revenant Legion. The same characters we have been following (including the Howl of the Hearthworld) have their stories wrapped up, or some probably wished it was wrapped up.This novel deserves all the praise and credit it will get. ADB has outdone himself, and written what I would describe as a science fiction novel that anyone could read and love. Again, well done. I am completely impressed.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2022

productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewTitle: That book will echo through eternity !
productPageReviewsFromOtherCountries.reviewDescription: What a shining jewel.What a splendid masterpiece.Saying that this book left me dumbfounded would be a dire understatement.Aaron crafted an outstanding volume and wove a story utterly captivating and poignant.He depicts in a breathtaking way one of the most tragic stages of the Heresy : the battle for the Eternity Gate.Aaron delivers golden information about the Blood Angels and Sanguinius (the ever tormented Angel).And also about the World Eaters, who they were and what they became.Despair is everywhere.Doom is dangerously looming like threatening clouds before a storm.Terra lies in tatters and mankind is aghast.No one would blame the survivors for giving up. They've already been holding on for so long.No more could and should be asked from them.But they hold on. They fight. With uniyelding defiance.Even though the outcome has already been decided by blood-thirsty monstrosities.Even though they're sorely outnumbered.They all fight. Astartes, humans, Primarchs.And the result is quite simply epic.If there was just one book of The Siege of Terra series you should read fellas, that's definitely this one.I cannot recommend that book enough.Don't straggle guys !!PS : seeing Sanguinius kicking Angron's sorry butt is absolutely priceless!

bookDescription: When aliens invade, a generations-long struggle begins against an impenetrable enemy in this sci-fi epic from the Hugo and Nebula Awardâ€“winning author.The Entities have arrived on Earth, fifteen feet tall with impenetrable defenses and inscrutable motives. As conquerors, they have no demands, no explanations, simply harsh consequences should they be challenged. Releasing a plague and plunging the world into a new Dark Age, the Entities seem unbeatable. But, one family at leastâ€”the Carmichael clan led by Colonel Anson Carmichaelâ€”will never give up the resistance.THE ALIEN YEARS is an epic story told over multiple generations by master of thoughtful science fiction Robert Silverberg. Can ideas of freedom survive in the face of an overwhelmingly powerful enemy? "A remarkable study of human endurance and patience that belongs in most SF collections." â€”The Library Journal"Sobering and frighteningâ€¦. Silverberg's rich characters, his dead-on-target vision of modern society, his mastery at building tensionâ€”all are in evidence in this notable outing from one of the very best." â€”Publishers Weekly

productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2025

productPageReviews.reviewDescription: Robert Silverberg's The Alien Years, one of his later works, is a tale of alien invasion. Mankind can do nothing to stop the aliens, but at the same time, the aliens' intentions are inscrutable. There is minimal interaction with humanity until some human attempt at striking back place takes place. This begins as simple as stopping all electricity to a worldwide plague that kills half of humanity. Eventually things settle down with humans psychically controlled into mindless tasks with some human actively collaborating with the aliens, but never learning their true intentions. One family across several generations keeps up the fight, coordinating a worldwide resistance movement but to no avail. Eventually, after 50+ years, the aliens pick up and leave without any reason or rationale.Given the long time span, the story jumps in time and the family goes from children to young adults to elder statemen. Much time is spent displaying the multiple forms that different people adopt to accommodate and learn to live in a very different world. By the end, most of the humans alive have never lived without the alien presence signalling a new beginning for humanity.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2022

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: Three and a half stars, if I could give a half.  Good, but not great.
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: First, what I liked:Silverberg does dialogue pretty well.  That kept my attention.He also does a good job with his descriptive language.The pacing is mostly on point.Now, what I didn't like:-- A few times, things just happen and people just behave in certain ways because the plot needs them to.  I kept thinking, "That's not how that would go down, in real life."-- The chapters are set up as time gaps (e.g., "Five Years Later", "Ten Years Later", etc.).  That allows Silverberg to cover a great deal of time in the book, but it comes at the expense of the characters.  We see characters as pre-teens, and then in the next chapter, they're in their 30s.  The Alien Years is a human story, but his way of telling it doesn't let us connect with the humans much.-- The ending ... It just doesn't work.  I won't go into spoilers, but I found it too abrupt.  I kind of see what he was *trying* to do, but he didn't lay the groundwork for it.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on January 4, 2022

productPageReviews.reviewTitle: A very good story about human nature while facing an undefeatable alien invasion!
productPageReviews.reviewDescription: One day, unannounced, the Aliens arrived. Their ships caused massive destruction not by war but simply by landing and setting massive unintended fires. Mankind tried to communicate with them but their efforts were useless.  The aliens were so far advanced that we were less than ants to their technology and mental capabilities. The aliens never tried to communicate with humans but they were telepathic and could force humans to do their will by simply pushing  what they wanted done into the minds of the Earthlings.Everytime mankind tried to drive the aliens off of the Earth their efforts lasted only seconds. The aliens retaliated quickly and efficiently. The message was clear, try to hurt us and we will strike back in a million fold worse manner. The aliens were so far advanced that it was like fighting Godsâ€¦â€¦This is an excellent story. Yes it is Sci-Fi but little was told about the aliens or their technology. The story is about how mankind reacted to being so easily conquered and subjugated  by a vastly superior race. Some people became collaborators, some tried to resist and Â½ of the worldâ€™s population died.No one knew who the aliens were, where they came from or what they wanted. The story is about how people lived under total domination and survived in their own way. That is what makes this story great. It is probably very close to the truth of what will happen when we finally meet a race of aliens that may be millions or billions of years more advanced than we are.I like the story and I rated it 5 stars.
productPageReviews.reviewedIn: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2017
